PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becoming more polarised-that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer, profiting from Australia's mineral wealth, whilst pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

That, of necessity, the Federal Government take action that ALL Australians SHARE THE WEALTH of their country by the transfer of resources to income security, health care and housing. Therefore, your petitioners urge that:

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. Has the Minister received any complaints about delaying tactics allegedly adopted by the Commonwealth Government, complaints which have been made before and by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in relation to the handling of Commonwealth compensation claims? If so, what action has been taken with respect to those complaints?

—I think there have been complaints about delays in this area but I am not aware of complaints about delaying tactics. I would appreciate clarification from the honourable senator that he is referring to delaying tactics, as against some problems giving rise to delay. I think there is a difference between the two ideas. I am not able to give him a final reply anyway. I understand that there have been some problems with delay. If the honourable senator can clarify the question I will seek an early answer for him.

—Mr President, I can perhaps clarify that by way of a supplementary question. I ask the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General, or whatever he is, whether he is aware of a decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in August this year which referred to delaying tactics by the Commonwealth Government in a compensation claim having aggravated the condition of the Commonwealth employee concerned. That is the particular matter to which I refer.

—I thank the Leader of the Opposition for clarifying his question. As I said before, I will seek a reply. I simply advise him that I am answering his question in my capacity as Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General, who is the Honourable Neil Brown.

—I ask a question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Today's Press statements attributed to the Executive Vice-President and Director of Nippon Steel Aust. Pty Ltd, Mr Teranishi, express concern specifically at Australia's lack of reliability as a supplier of coal. Is the Government in a position to reassure our trading partners of improved supply reliability in the next decade? In light of the improved liaison between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, will the Government ensure that continuing and regular discussions take place with the ACTU so that a consensus of views may be progressively evolved which are in tune with the changing industrial scene?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question Senator Archer asks is of considerable importance, not only in connection with Japan but also in connection with those many countries which are now energy hungry and seeking from us urgently energy resources to take the place of oil which is in dwindling supply. Unless these countries can rely upon getting resources regularly their own economic and even political conditions can destabilise. So the need for Australia to accept a responsible position is doubly important. Japan is a major trading partner. If we are to supply both the energy resource and the minerals, such as iron, bauxite or alumina, it is essential that they be provided in a continuous fashion, otherwise the mills themselves will fail. It is enormously in the self-interest of the Australian people that this should be, because the loss of export trade is a loss not just to the profitability of a company but also to the Australian people by way of the taxation that comes to them and its distribution to the various services.

ANSWER.PARA: In the last year, due to delay, at least $300m has been lost to Australia in revenue terms. As an example, I take the area of coal-mining. The number of days lost in 1979 was 232,600. In 1980 the figure was 710,700 although, as people know, that was affected by a housing dispute. Other areas, such as the stevedoring industry, were affected generally. Earlier this year I visited Japan and Europe. Wherever I went the one question that was asked in any critical fashion about Australia related to our industrial disputes and whether we could be considered as reliable partners. I believe that the ACTU is a responsible body. I believe that the ACTU would want to bring about effective conditions so that we can be reliable and so that we can provide jobs. Nevertheless, the question of reducing industrial disputes is of major significance to Australia. I repeat that this is not simply for the profitability of companies but to ensure that the world is not energy hungry and that the profit that is derived from the exploitation of minerals can, in its due share, be passed back to the people of Australia by way of higher living standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to a paper, circulated yesterday, which detailed how high income taxpayers with extensive farming interests could defer for at least three years the payment of a $60,000 tax assessment and reduce ultimate tax liabilities by $2,500 by lodging $100,000 in an income equalisation deposit for only 366 days on which 9.5 per cent interest would be paid to the depositor. I ask: Does the Government approve of such actions? If not, why did it enact the provisions which facilitate them? Further, will the Minister seek from the Prime Minister a guarantee that he, his wife, his family or her family or any of the 50 per cent membership of his Cabinet, who are ideally placed to avoid paying tax in this way, are not availing themselves of this provision? Will the Minister table this guarantee in the Senate before the end of this week?
—I have not seen the paper although I am aware of its existence.
—The Treasurer had a copy yesterday.

—I do not need Senator Walsh's help. It is not very helpful at any time. I will look at the paper. As to the first part of the question, I will seek any further information that would be of assistance to Senator McLaren. As to any suggestion that this practice might benefit Ministers or members of Parliament, we have a provision for disclosure and we will in fact be implementing thoroughly the recommendations of the Bowen Committee report. I will look at the whole of the question. Senator McLaren may be sure that the Prime Minister, in his supervision of the disclosure provisions in respect of his Ministers, and the Ministers themselves will observe impeccably the rules regarding self-interest or pecuniary interest. If there are further matters to be added, I will add them by way of response to Senator McLaren.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I did ask Senator Carrick whether, when he seeks this guarantee from the Prime Minister that the Prime Minister and his Ministers are not availing themselves of this provision, he will table that guarantee in the Senate this week. We know already that perhaps the Prime Minister oversees these matters but the public is not aware of what is going on. That is why I seek that this guarantee be tabled in the Senate.

—I will draw the attention of the Prime Minister to that request. I take it that, since Senator McLaren has asked that question, we will see a voluntary disclosure now by all Australian Labor Party members of Parliament, including farmers, as to whether they or any one of them will avail themselves of this or any other pecuniary interest.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to his statement on the conditional decision to commit our Defence Force to the Sinai peacekeeping operation. Does the Government attach equal importance to the two arms of the Camp David Accords-the Israeli withdrawal from Egyptian territory in the Sinai and the solving of the problem of Palestinian autonomy? Has the failure to achieve a just and honourable solution to the Palestinian problem been the cause of great damage to the strategic position of the Western world in the key Middle Eastern area? In the autonomy talks to be held between now and next January between Israel and Egypt, will a marked change of attitude on the part of both sides be necessary if any significant progress is to be made? When the Minister said that our involvement in the Sinai peacekeeping force was on the 'understanding that all the parties to the Camp David Accords press forward with a continuing peace process in the Middle East', does this mean that our force will not be committed to the Middle East unless there is some substantial progress towards a solution which is just and honourable to both sides of the Palestinian problem?

—The Government's decision on the Sinai peacekeeping force relates specifically to its belief that there is a possibility of settling amicably and peaceably one of the three or four factors that have bedevilled the Middle East, be it the Sinai, the Gaza Strip, the West Bank or the Golan Heights. The fact is that there appears to be-it has been reiterated by both Israel and Egypt-a likelihood that, in the months immediately ahead, Israel may withdraw peaceably its forces from the Sinai. If that is so, one of the significant trouble spots will have reached a successful solution. It is towards the end of seeking peace by those means that we have put this together. The fact of the matter is that the business of maintaining peace will require quite often the responsibility of earning that peace. Australia must help in that; peace is not achieved by standing by and shouting on the sidelines. There are a number of other sections to Senator Hamer's question relating to our attitudes towards Palestinian autonomy and the conditions attached. Senator Hamer has available to him the Prime Minister's speech. I think it best if I refer the remainder of the question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and seek a more detailed response to the other parts of his question.

—I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister, in view of the latter part of his answer, whether he will try to secure from the Prime Minister some undertaking about what, if any, diplomatic initiatives the Australian Government will be taking to see that the second part of the Camp David Accords, relating to Palestinian autonomy, is brought to the forefront of the thinking of both Egypt and Palestine and other associated powers so that it may be resolved as quickly as possible?
—I will be happy to add that question to the other questions and seek a response from the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport to a question I asked on 3 December 1980 and a speech I made on 22 September 1981 about airport curfews. As the Airbus has now been operating for some time, will the Minister advise the Senate of the noise decibel readings from the monitoring stations at our airports? If these readings are at or below the accepted international criteria for noise levels, as defined in Federal Aviation Administration Part 36 and International Civil Aviation Organisation Annex 16, can the Senate be advised when the Airbus will be allowed to fly outside curfew hours, thus maximising its utilisation and helping to keep air fares down?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It so happens that I have a table showing noise level comparisons for various aircraft, including the Airbus. At a later stage I will seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard. It is a fact that the particular noise levels to which Senator Collard referred have been tabulated. The results confirm that the Airbus has overall noise levels lower than those of any other airline jet aircraft in operation in Australia. In particular, the take-off noise of the Airbus is significantly lower than that of the DC9, the Boeing 747, the Boeing 737, the Boeing 727 and the DC10, and only marginally higher than that of propeller driven aircraft, particularly the Fokker F27. The Airbus also has low noise levels on approach to landing, although the difference is not so marked in that mode of operation. The Airbus meets the international noise certification standards of ICAO Annex 16. It also meets the standard of the United States Federal Aviation Authority's regulations in Part 36.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has informed me that a decision on whether the Airbus will be permitted to operate in curfew periods at airports will not be made until he has received advice on the matter through the Aviation Industry Advisory Council and has considered the views of the particular communities involved. TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware that officers of his Department are giving information over the telephone to strangers regarding payments made to social security clients? I refer to a recent case in a regional office in New South Wales where an opposing solicitor was given a statement of the unemployment benefit paid to a person without the permission or knowledge of that person. Does the Minister approve of this breach of confidentiality? If not, will he give an urgent direction to his Department that information should not be disclosed under such conditions?

—I have not heard of the report that Senator Grimes has indicated. I can assure him that had I heard of it I would have had it immediately and urgently investigated. I not only do not approve but also cannot approve of that sort of behaviour because the Social Services Act does prohibit the disclosure of information except under very confined circumstances. Indeed, it requires my permission or, I think, the permission of the Director-General. I will have the matter followed up. In giving that answer, I do not, of course, necessarily accept that that is the situation. But certainly, if the allegation has been raised, I will have it followed up immediately.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. It has been authoritatively calculated that Australian consumers paid $1,115m in 1977-78 for the benefit of protecting the motor vehicle manufacturing industry. If this figure is adjusted for inflation and applied to each State in relation to the number of vehicles sold in those States, the cost to Western Australia this year is $131m and to Tasmania, $39m. This is more than $3,000 extra for every vehicle purchased. The purpose of the tariff is said to be to create employment and also to support infant industries. If the claimed employment benefits are apportioned to each State and balanced against the cost, Western Australia shows an annual net loss of $123m. It may interest Senator Watson to know that his State of Tasmania shows a net annual loss of about $20m. Victoria shows a net gain of $443m based on those calculations. Can the Minister confirm the conclusions reached from these figures? Will he suggest to the Government that it either make a commitment to reduce this protection or take other action to correct the imbalance of benefits and penalties between the States?

—I am in no position to confirm the figures which Senator Thomas mentioned in his question. I will seek to have those matters investigated and referred back to him. Nevertheless, the question that he chiefly asks is whether the Government will reduce this protection, which is available to the Australian motor vehicle industry, in such a way as to reduce the total impact on the States, as he suggests. Perhaps there are broader questions here which do deserve attention. The Government will not be taking any particular action which will be to the detriment of the motor vehicle industry and it will certainly be considering all the impacts of its various decisions while considering the reports of the Industries Assistance Commission in connection with the industry. I am in no position at this time to indicate when the Government may be making a decision on this matter. I will seek further information from the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs in respect of the question which Senator Thomas asks.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Did the Minister notice further reports in this morning's Press concerning the depressed state of the uranium industry, including references to 8,000 unemployed uranium miners and mill workers in the United States of America, and predictions that the troubled industry will remain in its economic slump for at least five years? In view of the addition last weekend of the Kakadu National Park to the World Heritage List and the unlikelihood of Australia finding markets for any further uranium, will the Minister undertake a review of the feasibility of future mining in the Kakadu Park region, especially the proposed Pancontinental Mining Ltd mine at Jabiluka? Could any such review take into account two factors: Firstly, the now imperative importance of protecting the Kakadu National Park from any pollution from stored waste material or polluted flood waters; and, secondly, the economic value to Australia of the Jabiluka proposals when the realistic costs of such environmental protection are taken into account?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some statements regarding the current state of the uranium industry and the current demand, but Senator Mason should take into account the fact that they relate to the immediacy of the situation. The fact is-I will look up the actual figures and give them to him at the end of Question Time-that some 200-odd nuclear reactors are operating in the world today, some 200-odd are under construction and something less than that again are on order. So prospectively there is something in the order of another 300 or 400, certainly 200-odd, to come on-stream for the future.

ANSWER.PARA: I have said before that, whilst the immediacy of the demand for uranium is not heavy, all indications are that it will be heavy as the decade progresses. I want to stress once again-I must stress this-that the best authoritative view in the free world is that there is no way that using renewable energy sources such as solar, biomass, coal or gas, the world will achieve an energy balance without a significant and continuous increase in the peacetime use of nuclear power. Equally, the scientists are pointing to the very grave dangers to the health and the ecosystem of the world of the overuse of coal in the disturbance of the ecosystem. So those who are criticising the general trend of the nuclear debate need to look at two things. They need to look at what would take its place and the dangers that otherwise would exist-economically, politically and to the health of the people. There is not a big demand for uranium at the moment. There may be, for some immediate years to come, some limitation on demand; but when I provide the figures Senator Mason will realise that there will be a significant growth in the nuclear building. He will note that the socialist President of France, Mitterrand, instead of abolishing his low water reactors, of which he had nine under construction, has now indicated that he will go ahead with six. So in socialist France those projects will still go on.

TALK.START.PARA: —In communist Russia too.
—Yes, in communist Russia too and in the world where there is a need for energy to overcome human poverty and human deprivation.

ANSWER.PARA: As to Kakadu, there will be a total protection by the Government in terms of its ecosystem. The World Heritage listing is subject to the nomination being protected by the host nation's rules and laws. The National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act provides legislative protection in Australia. Whilst there is no debarring of mining in the longer range future, Senator Mason should be aware of the arrangements that have been made with regard to the National Park. I see no reason why there should be a slowing down, particularly of the uranium mines now under contemplation, provided they conform with all the laws of the land. They will be subject to the normal world market forces. If they are and they abide by the protective laws of the land, I see no reason why they should not proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask the Minister a supplementary question. I am very pleased to hear the Minister say there will be total protection of the ecosystem in the Kakadu National Park which of course would include its streams and rivers. But I do want to press this point to the Minister: I did ask him specifically whether he would look at the conditions of the proposed Pancontinental mine at Jabiluka in regard to the possibilities of pollution of the ecosystem in the Alligator Rivers Region.

—I made it clear in my answer that we would make absolutely certain that there would be no pollution of the ecosystem. As at 30 June 1981 there were 243 nuclear power stations in operation throughout the world, there were 229 under construction and there were 55 on order. So Senator Mason will see that there are almost as many nuclear power stations under construction as there are now in operation. There are 55 on order, making a total of some 527 nuclear power stations. I do say to those who comment on this subject that many of those nuclear power stations have now been operating for over 20 years and are part of the ordinary domestic electric supply system in the world.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. It refers to the results of a survey announced last week on the effectiveness of 331 commercial sun screen preparations. I point out that that is only one of many similar surveys that have been conducted in the past. How important is the survey to consumers? Do these surveys act as an educational process? If so, is the incidence of skin cancer in Australia declining?

—It is a fact that Australia leads the world in skin cancer. It has the rather doubtful privilege of having the highest rate of skin cancer and the highest rate of melanoma, a fatal form of cancer, in the whole world. These are related to exposure to sun. I do not have a prepared answer, but I am advised that certain people are particularly susceptible to developing skin cancer and that considerable education is required in this country concerning the need to wear hats and the use of appropriate screening. It is a fact that a series of publications have pointed out that some sun screen compounds have, on testing, proved to be ineffective and a small number have proved to be quite effective. This listing, therefore, is a very important service. It is one that should be widely known and widely publicised so that the Australian consuming public can have access to and a choice of effective preparations. I repeat that there is a real need for Australians to become users of sun screen preparations in a very systematic and educated way.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, is a flow-on from the answer the Minister gave to a question asked by Senator Mason on the future of the Kakadu National Park. By way of preface I refer to the second Fox report which warned about the capacity of the Alligator rivers system to cope with more than two mining operations at a given time. I marry that warning with the United States concept, whether Republican or Democrat, that certain parts of Alaska are exclusively off limits to any mining. Should I interpret the Minister to mean that, notwithstanding the World Heritage rating for Kakadu, he takes the point that each three or four years another mining operation will be started? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Mulvihill will know that whilst there is no existing mine in the area and none proposed-that is quite clear; Ranger and Koongarra mine areas are, of course, excluded from the park-the Government announced in 1977 that there would be no exploration, mining or development at least for the time being in Kakadu. However, the current plan of management for the Kakadu National Park sets out requirements to be met for exploration and mining to proceed should the Government so decide. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BEEF EXPORTS TO THE UNITED STATES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry concerns Australian beef exports to the United States. What is the current situation of the United States Farm Bill and its proposed amendments? Is it true that the United States House of Representatives this week passed a Bill banning meat imports from countries where chemicals used by an industry are prohibited for use in the United States? What steps have been taken by Australian diplomats and agricultural advisers, together with Australian beef industry representatives, to show the adverse and, I think, unnecessary impact this would have on the Australian beef industry? Can the Minister confirm that the interests of the Australian beef industry and Australian trade are energetically and effectively represented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A United States Farm Bill is before the Congress at the moment. The Bill has been passed with amendments in both the Senate and the House of Representatives. There are two separate amendments, one accepted in the Senate and a different one accepted in the House of Representatives, which touch on the area raised by the honourable senator. What is known as the Melcher amendment was accepted by the Senate and the English amendment was accepted in the House of Representatives. They are included in the separate versions of the United States Farm Bill and would amend the United States Federal Meat Inspection Act.

ANSWER.PARA: The Melcher amendment would prohibit the import of meat produced using chemicals not approved for use in the United States. Because of differences in environment and production systems, there are many chemicals used in Australian agriculture which are not used and therefore not approved in the United States. The English amendment is somewhat different in that it refers to chemicals positively banned in the United States. However, both amendments have the potential to cause considerable restrictions to our meat export trade. Both amendments have the appearance of measures to protect consumer health. On that basis they have attracted substantial congressional support. From the point of view of Australia, they are blatantly protectionist.

The use of agricultural chemicals in Australia, as in the United States, is subject to procedures to protect health including the establishment of safe residue standards. The differences between the two farm Bills are now to be resolved by the conference committee of the two Houses. The United States Administration is reported to oppose the English and Melcher amendments and hopefully will be able to obtain deletion of the offending passages at the conference stage. It would be well known to all honourable senators that the importance of the beef trade is well established in the Government's mind. It will always move energetically when the interests of that trade are threatened. Australia has already registered its concern on this matter to senior Administration officials and congressional leaders. At present the Government is reviewing its options for any further steps that could be taken.

The responsibility for soil conservation was and is within the States. Land and the preservation of land within a State come under State sovereignty. ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the concern that exists regarding soil conservation. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BEN LOMOND URANIUM MINES: RELEASE OF RADIOACTIVITY

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some little time ago, Senator Jones asked a question regarding the Minatome (Aust.) Pty Ltd Ben Lomond uranium mines. I intimated I would get information for him and I have done so. I apologise for the delay but it was necessary to carry out scientific tests to get the information. I am advised that following heavy rain in February 1981 water flowed into Keelbottom Creek through small holes in a waterproof membrane surrounding a stockpile of 3,500 tonnes of uranium-bearing material. This material was in its natural form; the radio-activity it contained had not been concentrated by processing and the stockpile was designed to prevent water filtering through it and being discharged into local streams. The Queensland Government subsequently monitored the quality of water in the area and has provided information collected by the Queensland Water Quality Council. The purpose of the limits recommended for gross radioactivity in drinking water, identified by the National Health and Medical Research Council and quoted by the Queensland Water Quality Council, is to signal the level at which further investigation of water quality is required. The dose obtained from daily consumption over one year of 2 litres of water at these limits represents 5 per cent of annual background radiation. For individual radionuclides, health authorities may allow higher concentrations in drinking water-for example, radium-226, up to 10 picocuries per litre; uranium, up to 1,000 picocuries per litre; and strontium-90, up to 30 picocuries per litre.

ANSWER.PARA: Information provided by the Queensland Minister for Water Resources and Aboriginal and Island Affairs is as follows: As to the gross radioactivity results in Keelbottom Creek, the creek was sampled upstream and downstream of the prospect area six times since February 1981, including 17 February. All results for gross alpha activity were less than 3 picocuries per litre, except one of four concluded due to sample contamination, and for gross beta activity less than 5 picocuries per litre. No significant difference between upstream and downstream results was determined. Recent results were less than one and four respectively.

As to the gross radioactivity results, the Charters Towers water supply has been sampled seven times since February 1981. All results for gross alpha were less than three picocuries per litre, and for gross beta were less than five picocuries per litre. Recent results were less than 1.5 and five respectively. The desirable maximum concentrations recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council for drinking water are: Gross alpha activity-Three picocuries per litre; gross beta activity-30 picocuries per litre. I am advised that the conclusions are, firstly, that there is considered to be no risk to humans and livestock consuming water from Keelbottom Creek or the Burdekin River and, secondly, that prospecting operations at Ben Lomond have had no significant effect on background radioactivity levels in streams draining the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The one hundred and eighty-eighth report is the annual report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts. It contains a review of examinations conducted by the Committee during the period to June 1981, issues arising out of our inquiries and other matters which the Committee regards as significant in its development during the year. In reporting this way to Parliament, the Committee has recognised its responsibility as a statutory body to report on its activities. The Committee has always taken the view that bodies established by the Parliament should report to the Parliament and therefore the Committee has been in the vanguard of encouraging increased standards and regularity in reporting in all areas of government endeavour.

SPEECH.PARA: The year contained two significant milestones in the development of the role of the Committee. Firstly, the inquiry into the pharmaceutical benefits scheme-chemists' remuneration-was the first matter to be referred from the House of Representatives to the Committee under section 8 (1) (a) of our Act since the Committee was reformed in 1952. I commend this practice to the Senate as I firmly believe that it is an extremely worthwhile method through which matters of concern may receive proper scrutiny. The second major innovation for the Committee has been the preparation of the discussion paper on internal audit, our one hundred and eigthy-fourth report. This discussion paper did not result from a specific reference or inquiry, but was the product of the Committee's longstanding interest in public administration, particularly those aspects of management which have a significant impact on the quality of administration within the Public Service. For the information of honourable senators, I will be tabling two further reports tomorrow-one, a handbook on Commonwealth financial administration and the other on the collection and dissemination of statistics which my colleague Senator Lajovic will report upon.

The Public Accounts Committee often uncovers areas of neglect which are common across the complete range of Government administration. In our annual report we have attempted to identify a number of problem areas to the Parliament in the hope that they will stimulate greater discussion and consideration of those important matters. I refer here specifically to three issues:

1. Accountability of statutory and other authorities: The Committee has been concerned for a number of years with the number of statutory authorities, Government-owned companies and other bodies which fail to submit, or submit late, financial statements formally to the Auditor-General's Office for audit examination.

2. Follow-up of Committee's recommendations: The Committee is aware that within departments there is a very real desire on the part of officers to avoid where possible coming under the scrutiny of the Public Accounts Committee. However, we are not sure that departments apply their resources with the same degree of vigour to overcoming defects which have been identified in the Committee's reports. For this reason we are currently implementing mechanisms to monitor more closely the consideration of our conclusions and recommendations.

3. Senior management in the public sector: The Committee has become increasingly concerned through its inquiries of an inadequate level of professional management capability in the higher or senior echelons of the public sector. Accordingly, the Committee will be examining the selection and training of senior management in some departments during 1982.

The 1980-81 period has been a particularly demanding period in terms of the breadth and urgency of inquiries undertaken by the Committee. The Committee, therefore, wishes to place on record its appreciation to the Secretary, Mr Michael Talberg, and all its advisors and seconded and permanent staff for their untiring efforts during the year. In addition, the Committee wishes to thank all those who gave assistance to the Committee, particularly officers from the Department of Finance, Office of the Public Service Board and the Office of the Auditor-General who have continued to provide high quality professional advice and assistance as observers for all our inquiries. We are also appreciative of the work and valuable assistance of the Principal Parliamentary Reporter and his staff and other officers and staff of the Parliamentary departments who have supported the Committee in its activities.

In conclusion, I also wish to place on the public record my acknowledgement of the work of David Connolly, M.P., the Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee. Mr Connolly has a thorough and complete understanding of administration within the public sector and his leadership of the Committee has been noteworthy in that he has been a pace setter in the production of high quality reports. I believe that the Committee has also greatly contributed to the better administration of the Commonwealth. Senator Georges has also been a great vice-chairman of the Committee and supporter of David Connolly. Senator Georges's vast experience, his humour and his timely unexpected questions to often difficult witnesses have a tendency to bring out the truth of the matter. On the other hand, Senator Georges has a balance because he shows a gentleness and kindness towards participants who are new in their approaches to the Committee. I thank both of them for their interest in and support for the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Committee's one hundred and eighty-ninth report relates to an inquiry into the purchase of airport fire tenders by the Department of Transport following the unfavourable comments of the Auditor-General in his report for 1978-79. Those comments were fully substantiated in the course of the public inquiry, and leave the arrangements for contracts between the Walter Motor Truck Co. of New York and the Department of Transport open to considerable criticism. In all, 25 ultra-large fire tenders were ordered from the overseas manufacturer which went into liquidation in October 1980, leaving one contract incomplete.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Transport has consistently expressed its own satisfaction with its choice of the Walter fire tenders. It was not the object of the inquiry to question this view, but rather to examine the circumstances leading to their purchase and to investigate the problems and cost of repairs associated with their early operation which received public attention in the media and the Parliament. The Committee understands that the vehicles are now in fact operating satisfactorily. The Public Accounts Committee was particularly concerned to investigate allegations that specifications prepared within the Department of Transport gave a distinct advantage to an overseas manufacturer. The advantage was exacerbated when tenders from 11 manufacturers were assessed by a small committee whose composition was essentially the same as that which drew up the specification. As the report reveals the practices followed by the Department of Transport in ordering 25 fire tenders to the value of $4.2m dollars were not above reproach. The Committee has already brought about a review of those procedures aimed, I am sure, at preventing future circumstances which call into question the personal and professional integrity of some of its employees and reflect badly on the management of the Department as a whole.

The saga of the purchase of fire tenders for the 31 airport facilities managed by the Department of Transport around Australia goes back to 1972. Changing Budget priorities, cancelled contracts, excessive delays in finalising contracts and problems in manufacture and commissioning had disrupted efforts to modernise and adequately equip the full time airport rescue and fire fighting service. When tenders were called in November 1975 for vehicles with a 6,800 litre capacity, it was a specification which the Public Accounts Committee considered to be developmental and which should have been managed in two stages, separating the development and testing of a prototype from a contract for the delivery of the number of vehicles, of proven design, required. The Committee had previously made this requirement known in reports tabled in 1972 and 1976.

Throughout the inquiry the Department maintained that it had not engaged in the production of a prototype and that an order for the full number of vehicles required was the appropriate procedure. Semantics aside, this action resulted in a situation where the Department of Transport received 16 vehicles all of which required essential modifications and repairs during training and in their early operational life. It is significant that the modification and repairs were particularly needed for the power-divider, a new feature in the Walter line of fire tenders.

The cost to the taxpayer of repairs, modifications and maintenance to put 16 new vehicles into duty approached a quarter of a million dollars in the period from their arrival in August 1978 until 30 January 1980. Most of this considerable cost was attributable to the initial order for 10 vehicles delivered in 1978. It is worth pointing out also that in the period from their commissioning until 30 June 1980, the 16 vehicles were out of service for a total of 1,542 days. In defence of the manufacturer, it should be made clear that many repairs and all modifications were honoured under warranty arrangements and often beyond the requirements of the warranty. Labour costs, however, were met by the department.

The aspects of the initial contract which were of concern to the committee included the failure to meet the then requirement for Australian industry participation in a large overseas contract. Regrettably, urgent delivery was a more prominent consideration. Relations between the Department and Australian manufacturers are poor, partly attributable to inadequate consultation on the part of the Department and its judgment that they could not meet the technical requirements of the specification. The report draws attention to the fact that the Department of Transport failed to check the financial viability of the contractor. In view of the fact that poor quality control during manufacture was a major contributor to vehicle defects, it is worth noting that no arrangements were made for the monitoring of the production.

I welcome this report as an important example of a lack of proper accountability within government administration. During the course of our public inquiry I personally maintained a high level of interest in this inquiry because I believe it displayed an example of poor management on the part of the Department of Transport-a practice that I believe this Parliament and committees of this Parliament have a duty to prevent. I sincerely hope that the Department of Transport will heed the suggestions incorporated in the report for improved management and accountability. A number of allegations were made that the Department deliberately designed Australian manufacturers out of its specifications and out of the contract. Serious allegations were also made that a former head of the fire services section acted subsequently in a business way with the Walter organisation. There was also a problem in relation to the cancellation with Chubb of the United Kingdom of 12 rapid intervention vehicles. I believe that these examples and further examples which I will mention highlight not only gross negligence but also gross contempt.

I wish to draw particular attention to a number of aspects of the report while recommending at the same time that all those who are concerned with airport safety and transportation in general read the full text of the report. Firstly, I will put some views on Australian industry participation in contracts such as that for airport fire tenders. The three contracts which were under scrutiny for a total sum which grew to $4.3m went to an overseas company which produced 16 vehicles before it went into liquidation leaving an unfinished contract for nine vehicles which were to have been completed under arrangement by an Australian company, Wormald International (Aust.) Pty Ltd, in Victoria.

It seems short sighted that the Department of Transport did not more closely examine the capability of Australian industry to produce its requirements for ultra large fire tenders. I believe it passed up a golden opportunity to encourage Australian manufacturing industry. In fact, I believe it deliberately went the other way. I make the point that monitoring of quality control-a major disaster in the American contracts-is much easier and cheaper within Australia than overseas. One of the problems we detected, which we mentioned in the report, concerned the lack of satisfactory monitoring and liaison. In fact, no use was made of Australian trade commissioners overseas in assessing the credit worthiness of this overseas supplier. Indeed it was a retrograde action on the part of the Department of Transport that it did not seek out from our overseas contacts a better analysis of the performance and creditworthiness of the Walter company.

I express my concern also that a subsequent contract for rapid intervention vehicles, also needed for rescue and fire fighting services at airports, apparently was awarded jointly to two Queensland companies not experienced in specialised fire tender production. Until proven otherwise, I will continue to show a lack of confidence in the Department of Transport until it improves its track record. I move to the deficiencies of the machines on their arrival in Australia. About $250,000 was required to make these units serviceable. This was at a time when Australia's airport safety standards were waivering on the brink of not meeting international safety standards. This is a very serious charge. The report gives details of the supposed exhaustive and rigorous tests conducted on the prototype in the United States of America.

What went wrong was that all 16 vehicles had to be modified to overcome what can only be described as defects associated with the design of the power divider. I will explain that. The machine was a single engine unit as opposed to a two unit engine where one engine was used to drive the truck and another was used to drive the water pumping mechanism. Appendix 14 on page 80 of the report shows that 27 defects were reported initially by the Auditor-General and that another seven subsequently became evident. The power divider-this is the feature of the machine which was not of proven design in the Walter fire trucks-was the major fault among 16 fault types which required some upgrading of the vehicle design of all the vehicles. We draw attention to this in conclusion No. 7.

It seems that the problems associated with the Walter design are not yet over. It is reported within Australian industry that the former Walter agent, Wormald in Melbourne, which took over the uncompleted contract for nine machines of the 9,100 litre capacity had experienced real financial difficulties as a result of taking over this work.

I conclude by saying that there are some important lessons to be learned from this inquiry into purchasing procedures of the Department of Transport. Firstly, the Public Service must consider what it can do about its officers whose management, skills and judgments seem to have been called seriously into question. Secondly, procedures must be reviewed to avoid further scandals which reflect badly on a Government department and further alienate Australian manufacturers of fire tenders who have managed to win overseas contracts but not from the Department of Transport. In fact, they have managed to win substantial contracts from the Australian mining industry but have still failed to win those from the Department of Transport. Thirdly, the total cost of contracts must be considered when tenders are assessed and balanced judgment must be made about what is best for the Australian taxpayer. I believe greater liaison must be established with and more use made of overseas trade commissioners to assess credit worthiness and performance ratings. With those remarks, I commend the reading of the report to honourable senators.

The statement read as follows-

The Committee's 190th Report refers to an inquiry into Petroleum Royalties and Excise. This inquiry was undertaken in response to questions raised in the Auditor-General's reports on a number of aspects of the assessment, collection and verification of revenue due to the Commonwealth in respect of production from the Bass Strait oil fields.

In particular the Auditor-General was not satisfied that the procedures followed in accounting for and sharing royalties and fees between the Commonwealth and the State of Victoria complied with the relevant Commonwealth legislation or indeed that sufficient action was being taken to ensure that all revenue due to the Commonwealth was being collected and accounted for by the appropriate authorities.

One of the difficulties to which the Auditor-General drew attention was the failure by the then Department of National Development and the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs to finalise satisfactory arrangements for the verification of the value of production from the various fields in Bass Strait and consequently of the royalties and excise payable by producers to the Commonwealth.

The Committee was appalled to find that it had taken 12 years, from 1968 to 1980, for a determination to be made by the designated authority as to the well head value of the petroleum produced and that for this period the final assessment of payments to be made by producers was left unresolved. The Committee regards this situation as completely unsatisfactory. It is convinced that the whole episode reflects unfavourably on the administration of offshore petroleum development in Australia and on the attitudes of the departments concerned which should have acted more promptly to establish the role of the designated authority and protect the interests of the Commonwealth.

The Committee was also informed that because excise varies according to the size of the field by which it is produced it is necessary to draw up a systematic method by which end products are allocated back to the various gas and oil fields in the Bass Strait production area. In addition a mass balance procedure is required to measure the difference between the assumed total input of components to the processing plant and the measured output of end products. These complicated procedures, although by no means precise, are essential for the calculation of royalty and excise payments. However, the Committee found that these procedures had not been properly documented and it is only now in the process of being completed.

The Committee concluded from this evidence that departments had given advice to ministers in the mistaken belief that the information required to enable ministerial decisions to be carried out was available. It was obvious to the Committee that there had been inadequate liaison between the policy departments developing the program and the department which was to administer it.

In view of the significance of the excise levy the Committee believes that departments have been negligent in not ensuring that adequate procedures were in place. Errors in the collection of excise could exceed plus or minus $10 million per annum and the Committee strongly condemns an administrative system which allows such a situation to occur and remain unresolved.

During its inquiry the committee considered the legislation passed in 1980 following the agreement reached between the Commonwealth and the States as to the administration of off-shore petroleum resources. In essence the legislation which has not yet been proclaimed is intended to give effect to the Government's intention to share power over and title to the seas surrounding Australia with the States and the Northern Territory. Commonwealth legislation is to apply beyond the three mile limit and State legislation within the three mile territorial sea. Mining operations beyond the three mile limit are to be under the control of a joint authority consisting of the relevant Commonwealth and State Ministers. In the event of disagreement, the views of the Commonwealth Minister will prevail.

The Committee's examination of this legislation has raised doubts as to the extent to which its stated objectives will be achieved. Having regard to the powers retained by the Commonwealth and the overall constitutional situation it is the Committee's view that ultimate authority and responsibility over the territorial sea remains with the Commonwealth.

Accordingly the Committee considers that it would have been more appropriate for the legislation to have provided for the joint authority to function both in relation to the territorial sea and the adjacent areas, with particular functions being delegated to the State designated authority as appropriate.

The Committee has therefore recommended that, prior to proclamation, the legislation enacted in 1980 be re-examined and discussed with the States with a view to amendment to extend the powers of the joint authority.

The Committee was also concerned that the position of the Commonwealth in relation to the collection of money does not appear to be adequately safeguarded under the legislation. Those responsible for the collection of royalties are State Government officials who are under no obligation to furnish full explanations to the Commonwealth. While the Committee believes that the State officials have co-operated fully in exercising their responsibilities, we have noted recent evidence given to the Victorian Public Accounts Committee indicating that the State authorities are unable to verify information provided by the producers upon which royalties are assessed. The Committee is strongly of the view that new methods should be determined to make relevant authorities accountable to both Commonwealth and State Parliaments. We have suggested that future reviews be conducted jointly by the relevant Commonwealth and State Parliamentary Committees.

The well-head value concept of assessment of royalties and excise is an unnecessarily complicated procedure and one which has not been favoured in other countries which exploit off-shore oil resources. In the Committee's view further consideration should be given to the procedures followed overseas with a view to adopting a simpler and more administratively satisfactory solution to our own needs.

Mr President, our report contains a number of recommendations which we believe will assist in overcoming the delays and complications which have characterised the administration of off-shore petroleum resources up to this time and will help to prevent similar difficulties arising in the future.
I commend the report to honourable Senators.

The speech read as follows-

I remind honourable senators that on 27 August 1981 I tabled in Parliament the Report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission on its recommendations for the calendar year 1982 which was in response to the Government's guidelines for financial assistance for schools in the States and the Northern Territory. The guidelines also included provision for some expenditure in the Australian Capital Territory for certain of the Commonwealth's specific purpose programs; funds for these programs have been appropriated for ACT schools in the normal Budgetary process for the 1981-82 financial year.

The Government has accepted all of the Commission's financial recommendations in its Report for 1982, apart from changes in relation to the Transition Program which the Government itself has made following consultations with the States, the details of which I will be taking up later in this speech. The Commission's recommendations were based on the policy and financial guidelines for Commonwealth education programs issued on 4 June 1981.

The estimated overall value of the Commission's recommendations for 1982 is $1,008.1m, an increase of some 4.6 per cent in real terms over expenditure in 1981. Most programs will be at least maintained in real terms, while others will be increased. The only decreases relate to Capital Programs for government schools which have undergone a reduction of $6.3m in real terms compared with a total Commonwealth expenditure on government schools of almost $480m, in the Special Projects Program to reflect the discontinuance of the school-level Innovations Program and in the Capital Grants Program for non-government schools where the reduction in real terms is occasioned by the non-supplementation of the new places element. Part II of the Bill contains provision for programs in government schools. Part III deals with non-government school programs.

General Recurrent Grants to non-government schools have been increased in accordance with movements in the government school standard cost and also to accord with the Government's election commitment to compress the present six subsidy levels to three funding groups. Group 1, replacing Levels 1-3, will receive per capita rates of 20 per cent of government school standard costs. Group 2, replacing Levels 4-5 will receive 30 per cent and Group 3, replacing Level 6, will receive 38 per cent. Group 3 schools will receive 40 per cent of government school standard costs in 1983.

In the guidelines statement, the Government announced several changes to the procedures for assessing non-government schools' subsidies. These included changes in the ranges of expenditure from private sources and the consideration of schools' disposable income. It was also announced that the Minister will allow schools disadvantaged by the changes in expenditure ranges to remain at a higher subsidy level for up to two years until they adapt their resources to the new arrangements and that the Government will review any cases where this is not achievable within two years.

New non-systemic schools, formerly assisted during their initial years of establishment by being categorised to Levels 6, 5, 4 and 3, in the first, second, third and fourth years of their existence respectively will, under the new arrangements, receive additional subsidies at the rate of 10 per cent, 7.5 per cent, 5 per cent and 2.5 per cent of average government school standard costs respectively in each of their first four years of operation.

General Recurrent Grants for government schools have been retained at their existing real levels, despite the fact that government school enrolments in 1982 are expected to continue the downward trend which became evident after 1977. In continuing to maintain this program at previous levels, the Government has in effect slightly increased the real per student allocation in government schools. Expenditure per student on recurrent resources in government schools has long since exceeded the expenditure targets set by the Karmel Committee in 1973.

In addition to direct Commonwealth expenditure for government schools, through programs administered by the Commission, the Commonwealth provides untied revenue-sharing grants to the States. These grants are available to State Governments to spend according to their own priorities and, along with funds from other Commonwealth and State sources, represent the bulk of the total funds for government schools, in fact, some 89 per cent; the States having the responsibility for the administration and delivery of educational services in government schools.

In November 1979, the Commonwealth announced the introduction of the School to Work Transition Program for young people aged 15 to 19 who were likely to be 'at risk' in the transition process. At that time the Commonwealth and States had agreed that concerted action should be taken from both quarters. The Commonwealth undertook to provide a total of $150m in real terms over five years from 1980 for the program and asked the States to match this expenditure dollar for dollar for government schools and TAFE colleges from 1982 onwards. This was designed to provide a total additional effort costing $250m over the five-year period. The program commenced in 1980, and the Commonwealth agreed to continue it in 1981 without a State contribution for that year.

In my statement to the Senate of 11 June, 1981, I indicated that because the States had not at that time indicated their readiness to make additional contributions to match the Commonwealth's expenditure in 1982, we felt compelled to take special action to increase significantly the resources devoted to transition activities. We therefore proposed to earmark up to $27m within the Commonwealth General Recurrent Grants to the States for government schools for expenditure on transition education. From that sum grants at the rate of $10 per pupil were to be provided to each government secondary school. We also proposed to earmark about $19m of government schools capital funds for equipment and facilities for transition education. Following consultations with the States since 4 June, they have, in general, now indicated that they have increased or propose to increase their recurrent expenditure on transition programs in schools and TAFE over the base year 1979-80 by amounts which approximate, and in some cases exceed, the amounts proposed to be earmarked.

In these circumstances, the Commonwealth no longer needs to proceed with the recurrent earmarking, since its principal objective has been met. On 22 September it was stated that we did not propose to proceed with the capital earmarking or insist on the allocation of a cash component to each government secondary school. This means that the Commonwealth's own expenditure on the transition program of $27m in 1982 will now be provided on the same basis as this year, that is, a reasonable balance in expenditure will be observed between schools and TAFE.

The Commonwealth will expect the States to continue their increased effort in transition programs and will seek the provision of information on a continuing basis to monitor progress with the combined Commonwealth and State contributions in schools and in TAFE.
The Commonwealth hopes that, in appropriate circumstances, the States will arrange for school communities to participate in the development of transition projects.

In accordance with the guidelines, this legislation will no longer contain provision for State Governments to request transfers of funds between the Commonwealth's general recurrent and capital allocations for government schools. The Commonwealth has allowed this provision over a number of years but as it tends to distort the basis of the Commonwealth's allocation of both recurrent and capital programs it should no longer, in the Commonwealth's view, be applied.

A change in the administration of the Capital Grants Program for non-government schools involves the absorption of the annual allocation from the unsupplemented triennial allocation of $25m provided for new places in non-government schools from 1981 to 1983 into the existing new enrolments element of the general capital grants allocation. As each non-government school building project requires Commonwealth approval, there will be no difficulty in seeing that this element of the general capital program is properly applied, and separate provision for this element in the legislation is no longer considered necessary. A further change in this program allows for capital grants to new non-government schools to be applied to the leasing of facilities for a period of up to three years.

The present Contingency Program for Refugee Children administered by the Commonwealth Department of Education will from January 1982 become part of the Commonwealth Schools Commission's programs. It will become one arm of the Commission's English as a Second Language Program, with the Commission's Migrant Education Program (retitled 'General Education in English as a Second Language') forming the other. Within the limits of the available funds, up to $750 per eligible student will be made available for intensive English courses for newly arrived immigrant or refugee children whose first language is not English.

Because of the difficulty in forecasting the number of such children arriving in Australia and their destination on arrival, no attempt has been made to provide a State by State allocation of the funds for new arrivals. These funds will be made available to both government and non-government schools in States as the Commonwealth is advised of the numbers of eligible students undertaking appropriate courses. Provision has been made to allow transfers of funds between government and non-government sectors and also from the New Arrivals element to the General Education element of the program. Funds provided for both elements of this program have been increased in both government and non-government sectors. The opportunity has also been taken of partially adjusting the distribution of the General Education in the English as a Second Language element among the States to accord with the results of a recent national survey of students of non-English speaking backgrounds.

Funds for the English as a Second Language Program for non-government schools have not been allocated on a State by State basis in the Bill. This reflects the Commission's wish to give responsibility to State Planning and Finance Committees for distribution of funds to non-Catholic schools. However, the Government intends that the allocations to Catholic schools in the various States and Territories will be in accordance with the recommended distribution in the Commission's Report.

An amendment has been made to the definition of 'program of ethnic education', to clarify the position of part-time ethnic schools in providing some instruction in the political and religious aspects of culture, as an adjunct to language instruction which will continue to be the major component of the course as a whole.

Funds for Special Education Programs will remain at the same real levels as in 1981. There are, however, changes in the legislative provisions for these programs to enable funds to be more widely used to provide services to handicapped children beyond those provided in segregated special schools, centres and classes. In line with this philosophy, the former joint program for the Integration of Handicapped Children has been apportioned to each of the government and non-government Special Education Programs as an identifiable element. To reflect the wider application of the funds, the basis of allocation of funds among States has begun to be changed from that of enrolments in special schools and classes to an overall school enrolment basis. The new allocation formula will be fully utilised within three years.

Non-government special schools will for the first time be eligible to participate in the General Recurrent Grants Program for non-government schools. They will not be subject to the assessment procedures applied to regular schools and will receive subsidies at the Group 1 primary rate.
In Joint Programs for both government and non-government schools, which are dealt with in Part IV of the Bill, major changes involve:

the increase in funds for the Country Areas Program and relaxation of the criteria by which eligible areas may be selected for funding; and discontinuance of the school-level innovations element of the Special Projects Program

The purpose of this BIll is to amend certain provisions of the Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Act No. 106 of 1977, which presently covers the giving of loan guarantees to non-government schools in the States.

In September of this year I announced that the necessary changes to the current Act would be the subject of amending legislation in the present Budget sittings. The effect of the amendments will bring the arrangements for the giving of loan guarantees in the States more into line with those for non-government schools in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory which are contained in the Independent Schools (Loans Guarantee) Act No. 23 of 1969.

The first amendment seeks to extend the coverage of the 1977 Act to include proposed as well as existing non-government schools in the States. Under normal circumstances proposed new schools do not have the necessary capital assets to offer as collateral in order to raise moneys for projects by borrowing. It is also the case with many proposed schools that they do not have an extensive parent body which can support heavy loan repayments. The widened definition of a non-government school contained in this amendment would then be similar to that used in Section 3 (1) of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act No. 135 of 1980.

The second amendment would extend the scope of a loans guarantee to cover the payment of interest moneys in addition to the repayment of principal moneys for the purpose of expenditure on an approved building project at a non-government school.

The Bill will continue to provide that a guarantee will not be given by the Treasurer unless the Minister for Education certifies that, (i) the terms and conditions of the loan agreement are satisfactory, (ii) in the absence of a guarantee a school authority would not be able to obtain a loan on satisfactory terms and conditions and (iii) a guarantee will not cover any part of the cost of a project that is or is likely to be the subject of a Commonwealth grant, including a grant under the advance approvals scheme.
The Bill also provides for an extension of the recovery provision to cover any payments made by the Commonwealth in respect of both the interest and principal components of a loan.

These changes will result in the scheme being more attractive to both proposed and existing non-government schools in the States which are faced with increased enrolment pressure. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Senator Mulvihill raised the issue of Vietnamese refugees employed on strawberry picking at Toolangi in Victoria, following the publication of an article in the National Times in which allegations of worker exploitation were made. I undertook to ascertain whether a Federal or State award applied to the industry and employees in question.

3. It has been determined that the 'Federal Fruit Growing Industry (Consolidated) Award 1976' has application to employees engaged in the strawberry picking industry in Victoria who are employed by employers bound by the award. However, as foreshadowed by me at the Committee hearing, the award is a 'closed award', i.e. it only applies to employees who are members of the employee organization respondent to the award.
4. The Bureau has not been able to establish that any employer mentioned in the article is a respondent to the award.

5. It appears likely to the Bureau that the employees concerned would be comprehended by the terms of the Victorian State 'Fruit Growers' Determination. This Determination applies to any person or persons engaged in the picking of fresh fruit and has common application to all employers in the industry concerned. It appears therefore, that the matter may fall within the jurisdiction of the Victorian State Department of Labour and Industry.

6. Senator Mulvihill also enquired as to the level of award inspections undertaken during the last twelve months of employers with employees working at cleaning in Commonwealth buildings. He referred particularly to cleaners working in the Commonwealth Centre in Sydney.

7. I have ascertained this is an area to which no general federal award regulation applies in the States. Notwithstanding individual plant or industry awards that provide for cleaners, no cleaning industry award or awards covering the cleaning of Commonwealth buildings exist apart from in the Federal Territories. Both the Caretakers Cleaners and Liftdrivers (ACT) Award 1967 and the Cleaning Contractors (Hygiene and Pollution Control) Industry (Northern Territory) Award 1978 have been declared common rule by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Contractors covered by these awards are inspected in routine programmed inspections and as a result of the receipt of complaints.

8. Where no federal coverage exists, it appears that State awards may have application. For example in Victoria there exists the 'Cleaners' Determination and in New South Wales the 'Cleaning Contractors' Award. It is possible that the employment of cleaners at the Commonwealth Centre in Sydney is subject to the State award. As no federal award applies to these cleaners the Bureau has not been involved in the inspection of records relating to their employment.

9. Senator Evans asked for certain statistical information to be made available showing the number of inspections, the number of staff engaged in inspections, the number of breaches detected (or at least the percentage of breaches as a percentage of the number of inspections), the number of workers involved in such breach detections and the amount of dollar sums received (appropriately adjusted for inflation). Preferably, the information was to go back one or two years beyond the inception of the Industrial Relations Bureau.

10. As I indicated to the Committee, the information requested, to the extent that it is available, is a matter of public record. I also alluded to certain changes in statistical definitions that may have occurred over the relevant periods and undertook to provide qualifications to the figures where appropriate.

11. The information as available is provided at Attachment 'A'. It will be noted that statistics on the number of staff engaged in inspections and the number of employees involved in breach detections are not included. The former was unavailable prior to the advent of the Bureau, and the latter has never been statistically collected. However, the total average number of inspectorial staff positions substantively filled has been provided. This figure includes the inspectoral staff positions allocated to award inspection and observance activities, staff training the development activities, and award information activities (including receiving complaints). While this gives the number of substantively filled positions, the number of staff on average actually available for these activities is a lesser figure due to staff absences on recreation leave, sick leave, long service leave, etc.

12. Also, Attachment 'A' depicts the amounts of money recovered following the termination of monetary breaches over the relevant periods. The figures are solely in terms of the nominal dollar values recovered during the relevant period.

13. Essentially, monetary recoveries made during a particular period are all those amounts paid to employees in that period, in respect of breaches which may have been committed up to six years prior to the termination of the breach. This situation arises from the provisions of section 119 (3) which allows courts to make orders for the payment to employees of the amount of underpayments accruing in the six years prior to the proceedings but provides that courts may not make orders for payment of amounts accruing prior to this period. Therefore, the actual composition of the money recovered figure-in terms of the period to which individual components of the total figure relate, and in terms of the actual size of these individual components-is unknown and uncertain. Consequently the application of an index (designed to remove the effects of inflation and which only relates to the period in which the recoveries are made) to that figure cannot give a true reflection of the 'real' money value of recoveries made. In essence this qualification is so severe as to make any attempted discounting for inflation (or change in average award wages) unrealistic and misleading. Accordingly it has not been attempted.

14. Senator Bolkus sought information on the number of Bureau staff with migrant backgrounds and the languages spoken by Bureau staff. As indicated to the Committee the Bureau has conducted a survey of its staff which has provided this information.

15. Thirty-one Bureau staff including nine inspectorial staff were born overseas. Of these, nineteen including three inspectorial staff speak a foreign language. Languages spoken by these inspectors are Arabic, Polish, and Mandarin. The languages spoken by other staff born overseas are Italian, Czechoslovakian, Spanish, German, French, Armenian, Arabic, Turkish, Greek, Polish, Ukranian, Swahili, Dutch and Hindi. Fourteen staff who do not have migrant backgrounds, including three inspectors have claimed a knowledge of a second language. Languages spoken by this group are German, Malay, Indonesian, French, Dutch, Italian and Afrikaan.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate Senator Rae's helpful interjection, but I have a reason for incorporating the document in Hansard. A number of trade union members may not see the Estimates Committee report but they will see Hansard. This matter arose out of an article which appeared in the National Times as to whether there was exploitation by one Vietnamese middle man in regard to strawberry picking in Victoria.
—I incorporated it in Hansard this afternoon.

—I will still continue with the point I am making. An investigation carried out by the Industrial Relations Bureau showed that the people who were employed in the strawberry picking industry could be covered by a State award but not by a Federal award. The point I make is that perhaps there could be more liaison with the IRB as a Federal agency and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The crux of the problem is not the actual attitude of the employer to the employees; rather, it concerns what happens, for example, when a Vietnamese middle man is involved in situations such as have happened with Pakistani migrant workers in Canada and in one or two areas of France with guest worker Tunisians. Those situations concern how much such a person is deducting for commission when collecting pay on behalf of the workers. Bearing in mind the extreme detail supplied in this document, I will take this matter up when the Committee deals with the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Rather than wait for some action from the Victorian State Department of Labour and Industry, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) might indicate whether any feedback has been given to Mr Macphee, being mindful of the article in the National Times.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter I refer to, and in respect of which I will seek leave to incorporate a document not already in Estimates Committee A material, is a misunderstanding-perhaps that word should go in inverted commas-between Mr Conciliation Commissioner Walker and myself on a long-standing inquiry into alleged sexual harassment of female carriage cleaners in the New South Wales railway system. I took umbrage at the fact that although I raised this matter in June or July-the Senate resumed in August-there was no feedback as to what was happening. In my letter to Commissioner Walker I said, in the second paragraph:
Let me hasten to add I was not trying to influence any ultimate decision but to ascertain what progress had been made.

For my pains I got a lecture from Commissioner Walker when he brought down the decision. The man had the misfortune to be ill. If someone from his office had rung the office of Ian Viner and had let me know, I would have been more patient. I am so naive as to believe that, when one puts a question on notice in June or July, with all the modern office devices something surely could be received in August, without waiting for an ultimate decision in the matter. Without holding up the Committee, I ask for the letter that I wrote to Commissioner Walker, with Appendix B, to be incorporated in Hansard. It is dated 21 October. Commissioner Walker already has a copy. I do this as a defensive measure because another document relating to this case that went to Sir John Moore, to the Minister and to one or two other people was not very flattering to me. So this is a defensive measure. I ask that my letter to Commissioner Walker, with Appendix B, be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
