TALK.START.PARA: —Rather than allow the debate to run on for too long without referring to matters which have been raised by honourable senators, I thought I would intervene in the debate at this stage. Senator Rae drew the attention of the Committee of the Whole to the report to the Senate of Estimates Committee A which contains a couple of complaints, one with respect to a 3 per cent across the board cut on proposed expenditure and another in regard to the fact that further reductions in proposed expenditure were made by the Government without consultation with the Presiding Officers.

SPEECH.PARA: My advice in this matter is that, in accordance with the procedures for considering the Parliament's estimates, there were not negotiations, as such, between the Department of Finance and the parliamentary departments but rather discussions to clarify certain estimates. The Presiding Officers took into account the Government's budgetary guidelines involving a 3 per cent real reduction in certain administrative expense items in drawing up their initial estimates. But six bids across the five departments exceeded the guidelines and the Minister for Finance wrote to the Presiding Officers inviting them to review their bids with a view to bringing them within the guidelines or to seek exemption from them. In responding, the Presiding Officers held to their original estimates and the Government decided to grant a partial exemption from the 3 per cent real reduction for those items to allow the same amount of money in real terms. This decision enabled the Parliamentary Reporting Staff to receive the full amount of the bid previously in excess of the guidelines. The 3 per cent real reduction guideline and the same money in real terms were calculated after deducting non-recurring items from the 1980-81 expenditure base.

My advice is that there were no further reductions in the bids as suggested by the Commitee's report but it is true that, due to the tight timetable for Budget Cabinet and the difficulties in arranging discussions at a critical time due to the absence abroad of Mr Speaker and the changeover of the holder of the office of President of the Senate, there were no discussions further to the correspondence between the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) and the Presiding Officers. If there is anything further to be added to those remarks, it will be after examination of the transcript of what Senator Rae had to say. I think that is in part a response to the point he has made.

As far as Senator Jessop is concerned, I understood that the honourable senator was aware that the Government had not completed its consideration of the report to which he referred. Whilst it is the intention of the Government that there should be a debate on the report as Senator Jessop has suggested there should be, it is not possible for a final response to the views of the Committee expressed in that report to be put down in the Parliament this week. As I said before, I thought that had been made clear to Senator Jessop and I am sorry if there was any misunderstanding about it. As he said in his comments, however, that does not preclude any debate in this place by him or indeed by any other senator. Certainly I acknowledge the accuracy of those comments.

Senator Mulvihill raised a series of matters in regard to correspondence which he had incorporated in Hansard. I will ask the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) whether there is any response to those items of correspondence and let the honourable senator have an early reply.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to discuss briefly a matter which was raised and followed up by Senator Jessop and Senator Peter Rae; that is, the disrespect shown by the Executive to the Parliament and to honourable members and senators. In doing so, I want to refer briefly to the Parliamentary Library's appropriations. During the Estimates Committee hearings it was discovered not only that the Parliamentary Library had suffered a cut in funding of three per cent in some aspects but also that in one item-division 104.2.02-the cut was $123,000, which was in fact a cut of 18 per cent. This cut was made without any consultation. It got a quick reaction from the President and Mr Speaker. In the papers annexed to our report there is correspondence from the President dated 12 August, in response to the Government's cutback, seeking an assurance that the $123,000 which was cut back unilaterally by the Government would be restored. As far as I can ascertain, there has been no response to this request. Such a massive cutback has led to the situation in which, in the course of the Estimates Committee hearings, the relevant Parliamentary Library officer had to admit that the Library's salvation lay in the Additional Estimates. At page 27 of Hansard of 15 September, relating to Estimates Committee A, Mr MacLean, Acting Parliamentary Librarian, said that the letter of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) had some very odd statements in it. He said:
It has been decided that the same real level of expenditure in 1980-81 would be permitted in 1981-82.
He went on to say:
I must confess I find it difficult to understand a cut of 18 per cent.
Not only was the cut made but also it was attempted to be camouflaged in the context of correspondence from the Minister for Finance.

The other aspect of the Library's performance and function to which I would like to refer concerns the application of the Copyright Act. In the course of its deliberations, the Committee discovered that the Copyright Act is not being applied legally within the Parliament itself. That point came out in a number of instances on 15 September. In questioning, it was admitted by the Parliamentary Library officers that the Act was not being applied and that in fact advice was being sought from the Attorney-General's Department as to its application. On 21 September, on page 375 of Hansard of that day, Mr Greenwell from the Attorney-General's Department admitted that there may still be a technical infringement of the Act but that that was being looked at. The initial point of concern, of course, is that we have in application an Act which the Parliament itself finds difficulty in enforcing.

The other thing that worries me about the evidence that was given with respect to the operation of the Act is that we were led to believe by the Parliamentary Library officers that advice was being sought at that stage. From further inquiries I have been led to believe-I hope wrongly-that advice had been sought and that advice was given that the Parliamentary Library was in fact acting illegally, even though it may have been a technical breach; that the procedure that had been adopted and that had been declared to be illegal was still being pursued; and that no further advice is being awaited from the Attorney-General's Department. Once again I support the sentiments of Senator Jessop, Senator Peter Rae and Senator Douglas McClelland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. This evidences something in the nature of a problem. The Senate has developed a committee system and here we have a committee report but we are not allowed to speak to it at the time it is presented. If we cannot speak to it at the time that it is presented, there ought to be an opportunity for the Chairman, on behalf of that Committee, to give some lead in relation to the consideration of the matters raised by that Committee so that we have some sense of orderly progress. This afternoon a series of things has been raised, quite understandably, by various people in relation to the report before I, on behalf of Estimates Committee A, and any other member of the Committee have been able to explain it, and to add to whatever it was the Committee wanted to say. Clearly we have seen an example this afternoon, with Senator Watson talking about something the Committee did not say, or misunderstanding what it did say. It would have been helpful if I had had an opportunity to draw attention to the relevant part of the report and on behalf of the Committee to ask for some preference to be given to other members of the Committee to elaborate if they wished, before general questioning and debate took place. It is in that sense that I raise a point of order as to how we deal with the matters that are raised in the report as opposed to how we deal with other matters that any honourable senator is free to raise at any time, or how we deal with the situation where non-members of the Committee may wish to speak about matters that have been raised in the report itself.
—Is it the wish of the Committee that I call Senator Peter Rae? There being no objection, I call Senator Rae.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. I turn next to matters that were referred to in the report to the answer that has already been given by Senator Chaney, in which he impliedly acknowledged that there had been an established arrangement of consultation with the Presiding Officers, but that because of the urgency of getting the Budget completed, because there was a change in the presidency and because the Speaker was overseas, it was not possible for the further consultation to take place. If that is so, it amounts to an answer to the question that I asked, and that is that there is an acknowledgement that there is an established procedure which will be followed wherever possible in the future, and, if that is so, I think everybody can happily leave the matter. I would just like to clarify that that was the meaning of the answer.

SPEECH.PARA: I pass on-there having been some reference to one or two of the other parts of what has been said in the Committee's report-to page 3 and the reference to the Joint House Department. Some specific references were made there to consultancies, and I think they speak for themselves. Page 4 states:

In relation to the two Joint Committees administered by the Joint House Department, the proposed appropriation for the Public Accounts Committee in 1981-82 is $83,000-an increase of almost $18,000 over expenditure in 1980-81, while for the Public Works Committee the proposed expenditure is $60,000-a reduction of nearly $4,000 on the 1980-81 expenditure. Salary and overtime allowances for these two Committees are estimated to cost $186,000 and $86,500, respectively.

I think Senator Watson would have confused everybody by suggesting that the Committee had overlooked the fact that those two figures are quite separate in the report and are identified separately. The Committee went on to say:

Perhaps inevitably, the Committee made rueful comparisons between the funds generously provided to these two Committees-particularly the Public Accounts Committee-and the relatively minimal amounts made available to the Senate Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committees and Select Committees.

I draw the attention of the chamber-it is unfortunate that I am in effect replying to Senator Watson-to the fact that in no case was any specific reference made to a specific standing committee or a specific select committee, but rather to the whole of the Senate's committee system as opposed to the joint parliamentary committee system. I was drawing attention to the differing amounts which are made available, one to the joint system and the other to the Senate's own system of committees. The Committee went on to point out:

It is of interest to note that the average expenditure of the eight Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committees, the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and two Select Committees operating in 1980-81, was little more than $9,000 . . .
That is the average. It continues:

(Excluding salaries and allowances of staff), and the Committee was advised that the Department expects to be able to service Committees in 1981-82 within the provisions of a $117,000 vote (this . . . figure includes a proposed expenditure of $18,000 on the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, which the Senate administers).

The position is that Estimates Committee A was there drawing attention to the fact that for the purposes of operating the Senate's entire committee system, leaving aside salaries and allowances, the amount for one joint committee was almost the total of the provision for the whole of the Senate's committee system. I believe that is a valid point. It may be relevant for Senator Watson to show how busy, industrious and effective the Public Accounts Committee has been. I do not challenge that it has been any of those things. Estimates Committee A was drawing attention to the need or to the recommendation to the Senate that consideration be given to a proper balance between relative resource provision. This is the point. It may be that some other committees could produce just as many reports or more reports and even more effective reports or sit more times to do something else if they had the sorts of resources which are made available to the joint committees. The question is: Does the Senate wish to continue to have a very large amount of resources made available to the joint committees in which it participates, an amount which far exceeds that made available for the totality of the rest of its domestic committee structure? It is not a matter of competition between the committees saying that one does a better job than another, and it is not an attack on the committees saying that any of them do an inadequate job. Estimates Committee A was pointing to what ought to be the real balance of the resources made available. That was the point that was being made. I wish that I had been able to make that clear before Senator Watson spoke, but I hope that I have made it clear now.

Some other matters were referred to in the Committee's report which I believe amount to this: There was some concern about the way in which the Joint House Department had prepared the explanatory material for information in relation to the presentation of the proposed appropriations, particularly in the light of the fact that the Estimates committees have, over a period, with the co-operation of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) and with the co-operation of the Department of Finance and various other people involved, developed a system whereby it is possible to make comparisons and to be able to get a standardised form of presentation of the material whereby we are then able to cross-aggregate to get similar information provided by the various people seeking appropriations and able to compare and to follow through programs, or whatever it may be. It was regarded by Estimates Committee A, when it looked at the Joint House Department, that there was a difference which was of some relevance in the way in which the information had been presented and the way in which the Senate had been insisting that the rest of the departments, authorities and everybody else should present their information.

The Committee drew attention to some of the decisions that had been taken in the allocation of funds. At a time when cuts are being made it was pointed out that it seemed there were some rather extraordinary priorities being highlighted. I do not want to go into those; they are set out in the report. But the Committee compared the priorities that appeared there with the fact that substantial cuts were being made in books and periodicals and other items for the Parliamentary Library and whether we had our priorities right in the total allocation of funds. The Committee goes on to say:

Owing, however, to the paucity of detail provided in the explanatory notes of the department, and to the limitation on the time available to the Committee to examine all matters in sufficient depth, the Committee did not consider that it was able to do justice to its examination of the department's proposed expenditure and operations. Committee is of the view that further examination of the department is required, and therefore recommends:
That the following matter be referred to the Senate House Committee for inquiry and report:
The organisation, operation, functions and financial administration of the Joint House Department.

It has been suggested to me that as a matter of procedure I should, on behalf of the Committee, give notice that I shall move that the matter be referred to the Senate House Committee, that I will do so at the giving of notices of motion tomorrow and that at the same time I will set out the whole of the motion which would involve for the purpose of conducting such an inquiry the giving of some increased powers to the Senate House Committee which as an internal committee has been without the powers which are normally available to a standing committee or a select committee. In drawing the attention of honourable senators to that recommendation which was a unanimous recommendation from Estimates Committee A I have indicated that I will give notice of motion of my intention to move that that matter be referred to the Senate House Committee and that the motion will set out the terms for the constitution of the Committee so that it may conduct the inquiry. It has been suggested to me also that it may be appropriate if the President did not attempt to wear two hats in relation to this matter. He is normally a member of the Senate House Committee, but for the purposes of the specific reference perhaps it would be better if the President was not a member of the Committee but was able as one of the presiding officers to consider quite independently any report which is produced. That will be catered for in the proposed notice of motion which I will give tomorrow.

Having referred to those matters which are all to do with the Parliament, I point out that other matters are raised in the report of Estimates Committee A. But I would like you, Mr Temporary Chairman, to invite this Committee of the Whole to deal first with the matters that are raised under that section headed 'Parliamentary Departments' before proceeding to the other parts of the report when perhaps I could have the opportunity to refer to one or two things in relation to the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of Industrial Relations and the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the Committee to deal only with the 'Parliamentary Departments' section? The Committee has already decided, as I see it, to deal with Group A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that it is a matter of the honourable senators who are interested in that section of the report dealing with the Parliament being available and rising and perhaps those who wish to discuss some other matters holding back until it appears no one is rising to speak on matters relating to the Parliament. I would have thought there could have been an informal arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the sort of discussion that we have been having over the period I have been in charge of the chamber as Minister this afternoon does highlight the fact that some thought needs to be given to just what is it that we are doing with these Estimates committees and how we ought to deal with the results of them. It has certainly been my view-I speak now as a senator rather than as Minister in charge of the chamber-that Senate Estimates committees have admirably succeeded in opening up the minute detail of the Government's financial processes. Some interesting questions were raised by Senator Evans about items totalling $12,000 in a Budget which is of the order of $40 billion. That gives some idea of the sort of detail which we get down to but it does seem to me that there is some difficulty for us as a Parliament in dealing with these matters adequately if we try to deal with them not only in committee but also in this chamber which by definition has a limited time to deal with a great mass of detail. It is also extremely difficult if we re-run the reels of Estimates committees themselves for Government Ministers to give responses in a definite or satisfactory way, given that the range and the amount of detail are almost limitless and given that we bring before the Estimates committees a very large number of public servants who are available for very detailed questioning. Even they on occasion have to refer questions for subsequent answer. Indeed, Estimates Committee A has a whole booklet of written replies to questions which were asked during the hearings and which required follow up.

As the Minister who shortly will cease to be in charge of the Committee of the Whole and will leave it to my brother Senator Baume, I simply draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that I think there are very real difficulties. The great advance which Estimates committees have achieved is to expose, as I said, so much of the financial detail of Government to the Parliament and hence to the public. I think that is a notable achievement. To my mind that has not been followed up to the extent that the committees are then able to provide a funnel for important issues which ought then to be considered in this chamber, although of course on a quite ad hoc basis important matters are raised, not necessarily in sequence, and so on. Senator Peter Rae's appeal for us to direct our attention to the report of Estimates Committee A and other reports is, of course, a response-he is not responding to my concern-to a concern similar to the point which I have raised. But I make those comments because there is no discipline upon any of us as senators. We are free to rise and to address ourselves to any point, but it does seem to me that the value we get for the public, the Opposition and the Government is less than it would be if we had a slightly more orderly approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the report of Estimates Committee A in respect of the matters relating to the Parliament. In doing so I note the recommendation that was made by the Committee, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Senate House Committee for inquiry and report:
The organisation, operation, functions and financial administration of the Joint House Department.

I note that my colleagues from this side of the chamber, Senator Bolkus, Senator Evans and Senator Tate are members of Senate Estimates Committee A and therefore I assume they are signatories to that recommendation. I hope that my party will support the notice of motion which has been foreshadowed this afternoon by Senator Peter Rae, namely, to recommend to the Senate that the Senate House Committee should further investigate the matters set out by Estimates Committee A at page 5 of its report.

I mention this matter briefly because I fear there may be forces at work attempting to expand the operations of the Joint House Department to embrace control of the Senate and House committee secretariats, control of all joint committee secretariats, control of the Parliamentary Library, control of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and eventually, I would fear, control of the Senate and also the House of Representatives. The plan might be gradually to combine all these functions under the control of the Joint House Department. In other words, I suggest that honourable senators and members of the House of Representatives have to be very wary about the growth of bureaucracy within the Parliament itself. Might I say at the outset that I commend my colleague, Senator Young, for the excellent work he is carrying out as President of the Senate to protect the rights and interests of members of this House. I know from my own knowledge, in the occupancy of the position that I hold for the time being, of the excellent work that is being done by the President on behalf of all honourable senators.

I fear that the proponents of any plan that might have been considered have sat down and thought what an attractive bureaucratic organisational chart such a proposal would make. Perhaps they could even see jobs in it for themselves or for others around the place. I say this because I am sure that no one with any respect for or any real knowledge and understanding of the functions of the two Houses of Parliament would support such a proposal, let alone advocate it. I fear that the type of consideration that is ensuing in respect of the report of Estimates Committee A on parliamentary appropriations shows vividly the gulf that has developed in this Parliament between the powers and responsibilities of the Executive, the crumbs that are thrown to the back bench members of the Parliament on both the Government and Opposition benches and the growth of bureaucracy that is occurring not only within the Public Service but also within the Parliament itself.

As Deputy President, part of my responsibilities to the Senate include matters relating to Senate committees. The figures that are set out in the report of Senate Estimates Committee A are somewhat staggering. It rather staggered me to read in the report of figures relating to the two committees administered by the Joint House Department, namely, the Public Works Committee and the Public Accounts Committee. I say at the outset to my colleagues Senator Watson and Senator Georges that I do not for one moment disparage the excellent work they do as members of those committees on behalf of the Parliament. They do excellent work. But I point out that the committees have an appropriation for the operating expenses totalling $143,000 compared with an appropriation of only $117,000 for 11 Senate committees and the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence which is under the control of the Senate. In addition, inquiries that I have made in my capacity as Chairman of Committees indicate that the staff of the Public Accounts Committee is soon to be increased to 14 and the staff of the Public Works Committee is to be increased to nine. I remind the Senate that generally speaking each Senate committee has a staff of a mere three.

All governments will tell us and the Parliament that only a certain amount of the cake can be shared around. However, the Senate through its Estimates committees has a responsibility to examine the expenditure of parliamentary departments excluding, of course, the House of Representatives. It has a responsibility to examine the expenditure of parliamentary departments just as it has a responsibility to examine the expenditure of government departments. I venture to suggest from my reading of Senate Estimates committees' reports that all of the Senate Estimates committees have done an excellent job in consideration, study or investigation of various government departments. I suggest that the Senate must satisfy itself in respect of the departments over which it has control and, of course, also in respect of its own department, that the appropriations sought are justified and that the expenditure is being properly administered. It is apparent from the report of Senate Estimates Committee A that the members of the Committee may have uncovered matters of real concern to the Houses of the Parliament. For those reasons I trust that my party will support the foreshadowed notice of motion which has been mentioned by Senator Rae in his remarks this afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to reply to the remarks which have just been made by Senator McClelland. I regret that I was not clearer in my earlier exposition. The estimate of the Public Accounts Committee, which I think is of the order of $83,000, includes all expenses. It includes the cost of travel of staff and advisers and, because it is a joint committee, of members and senators. That amount also includes the cost of printing, stationery and all of those sorts of items. I think that Senator McClelland failed to recognise that these items are included as part of the Senate's general vote for its committees. I just wish to make that point because I would hate to think that we were not comparing apples with apples. We must include, when making comparisons, identical components of the aggregate. I think it is necessary to add up the total components. I just wish to draw the attention of the Senate to this matter. Apart from this matter, I concur with the remarks of both Senator McClelland and Senator Rae.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As an ex-member of Senate Estimates Committee A I want to compliment the Chairman and members of that Committee for the meat that is in its report which we are discussing this afternoon. I am glad that the Committee has recommended that the Senate House Committee inquire into and report on the organisation, operation, function and financial administration of the Joint House Department. This is something that has caused great concern over the years not only to me but also to other members of Estimates Committee A. I have expressed disappointment in this Parliament on many occasions. We have been advised by the Speaker of the other House that the house committees of the Senate and the House of Representatives have no powers whatsoever and that they function in an advisory capacity. This decision has caused a great deal of frustration among members of the Senate House Committee. I will not debate this matter now because I hope that when Senator Rae gives his notice of motion an opportunity will avail itself for us to make an input in respect of that motion. However, I am doubtful that that occasion will arise. Be that as it may, I will confine my remarks to repeating what is in the report of Senate Estimates Committee A. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: If this proposed reference is accepted in Committee of the Whole and by the Senate, a further motion relating to the proceedings and powers of the Committee would be required.

I hope that these proceedings and powers of the Committee will be of a permanent nature so that both the Senate and House of Representatives house committees have permanent powers and laid down procedures. The minutes of the Senate House Committee-at least this was the case when I was a member of that Committee-are very sketchy. I have had a brief respite from service on that Committee but I have now been re-elected. As I said, when I was a member of the Committee the minutes were very sketchy. Nothing was taken down verbatim. Nothing was ever revealed about what was said by members of the Committee. As a result members of the Committee came in for very stringent criticism from members of parliament who said that we were not carrying out our duties. It was not possible to prove to other members that we were in fact doing our best under the restrictions placed upon us in view of the fact that we were operating only in an advisory capacity.

Some time ago-I think it was last year-I suggested to then President Laucke that steps be taken to ensure that minutes of the house committees be circulated to all members of parliament so that they in fact can see what their elected members are doing. I hope that the Committee will agree with the proposal of Senate Committee A in this respect. I hope that its recommendation will be included in the Senate House Committee's terms of reference so that every member of parliament will be full aware of the deliberations and input of members who sit on these committees as their elected representatives. I do not intend to say any more than that on that subject.

However, I want to say a few words about the responsibilities of the various Senate Estimates committees as they are now set up. I was a member of Senate Estimates Committee A for a few years and during that time both the estimates for the Parliament and the Department of Administrative Services came under our scrutiny. For reasons best known to the Government the estimates for the Parliament and the estimates for the Department of Administrative Services have now been separated and are dealt with by two different Estimates committees. I think the reason for this is that members of Estimates Committee A were becoming very expert in asking questions on both the Department of Administrative Services and the Parliament. Both of these departments are very closely related in terms of their responsibilities to the Parliament and to members of parliament.

Senator Chaney gave us a little lecture a while ago and said that we ought to have pursued most of these matters when they were being considered by the Estimates committees. He said that we could have got our answers at that time. I have complained on many occasions that because of the way in which Estimates committees are now structured it is impossible to get answers. If the Minister does not want to answer a question he says: 'Oh, well, that is a responsibility of another Estimates committee'. One just cannot get answers. I have made requests on numerous occasions that some system be devised whereby the whole expenditure for one department can be considered together so that we can get an answer. Senator Withers used to take great delight when he was Leader of the Government in this place in saying to me and other honourable senators: 'Well, that is not the responsibility of this department. You will have to seek the information elsewhere'. Only a few weeks ago, when I was asking questions during an Estimates committee meeting, he jocularly referred to the way in which he used to handle us. The situation is still the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —What you mean is a full program evaluation across the board. Where it goes through a number of departments it cannot be undertaken by one committee. That is what it boils down to. You cannot follow something through.

—That is right; you cannot. It is necessary to run from one committee to another. At present we have eight Estimates committees. It is impossible for an honourable senator to do his duty on each of those committees properly if several of the committees are sitting on the one day. The problem that many honourable senators find themselves confronted with is that they cannot pursue the matters that they want to. One matter concerns the time I questioned the cost of the installation of a telephone for one of the Ministers. When I tried to ask that question in the examination of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, I was told that the matter was the concern of the Department of Primary Industry. When I pursued the matter with that Department, I was given the runaround again. I will refer to that matter when we come to the Estimates for the Department of Primary Industry to see whether some of the answers to the questions that I raised are now available to me. I have not yet received those answers and I am very concerned that the Government cannot provide them.

SPEECH.PARA: Some mention has been made of the staffing of committees. That matter too is of concern particularly now with the different party representation of the Senate. When we want certain matters referred to select committees, we are told that there are not enough honourable senators to do the job. Furthermore, even if there were enough senators, there is not enough staff to carry out the work. That is of great concern to me. For example, I raised a matter in this Parliament before the winter recess. This was a matter I wanted referred to a Senate select committee. The Government would not accept that matter but I was of the belief that, when we had the numbers in the Senate, that select committee would be set up when we came back for the Budget session. I am now told that it is not possible to set the committee up because there is not enough staff to staff all the proposed Senate select committees. I think that inhibits the work of members of Parliament particularly when it concerns important issues. I thought that my issue was very important. It was not a matter I drew out of the hat at the last moment. Some years ago I had the matter referred to a Senate standing committee. It was not able to handle the matter as it should have. The committee suggested the matter go to the Ombudsman but, when it did, he was not able to handle the matter. No report was ever tabled. I then sought to have the matter referred to a select committee--

TALK.START.PARA: —It could have been.

—I was steered off then and I have been steered off again this time. Senator Baume interjected to say that the matter could have been. When I raised the matter he said there was no need to do that because the matter was being handled. Events in the last week have proved that I was right and that the committee of inquiry should have examined what needed to be done. If it had certain people may not have been in the straits that they are now in. We may not have had very expensive court costs looming in front of us. Had the Senate taken on that job, it could have circumvented that. However, that is getting away from the subject.

SPEECH.PARA: What I want to say is that there ought to be sufficient staff available whenever a select committee is needed. Honourable senators should not be fobbed off with the argument that there is not enough staff available. Let us put the matter to the Senate. If the select committee is set up, it is the responsibility of the government of the day, whether it be the government of the present day or another government, to find sufficient staff to enable that committee to function.

On most occasions, Senate select committees do not take long to do their work. As a matter of fact we could have reserve staff set aside particularly for the manning of Senate select committees. At present if members of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats can gain the support of the Independent senator, a proposed select committee can be set up. I hope that no select committee is ever set up just to satisfy the whim of some individual. Honourable senators ought to be required to give certain proof that the committee is required. There ought to be a special staffing arrangement so that, whenever a select committee needs to be set up, we have the staff to do the job instead of having to take staff away from the standing committees. Goodness knows, those committees are very restricted in their staffing arrangements. We have had the occasion in this Parliament when we have had to second staff from Senate standing committees to staff Estimates committees. Those staff have to do that work as well as try to do the other work of the standing committees with which they are normally fully occupied. I hope that the Government will take notice of what I am saying in that respect.

Another matter I refer to deals with the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. We all know what a magnificent job members of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff do. I have taken it on my own shoulders, by way of observation in the years I have been in the Senate, to note the extraordinary work done and the workload imposed on the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. We all know it is not an easy job running up and down the stairs from the time the Parliament commences each day until it finishes-sometimes the next day. I refer particularly to the male Hansard reporters and the way they have to be attired in a collar and tie to carry out their duty. It is all right for the female staff who can come in here with an open-necked blouse. Nobody objects to that. We have set the precedent in the Senate over the years that male honourable senators do not have to wear a necktie. I am very pleased about that. I said, both in a letter to ex-Senator Laucke and in a speech I made here when the Parliament opened, how grateful I was that he allowed honourable senators to appear here neatly attired in open-necked shirts.

I am putting the proposition to whoever is responsible-I do not know whether it is the Presiding Officers or the head of the Hansard staff-to look at the possibility of allowing male reporters to do their job in an open-necked shirt or in a safari suit, if they are neatly attired. They can do this when away on committee work; nobody objects. Their work is enhanced by the fact they are not frustrated by wearing a necktie. I make the plea to the powers that be that they give some consideration, particularly with summer coming on-perhaps it could be done by way of consultation-to getting some recommendations for some dress reform for male Hansard reporters. I will pursue that matter further, perhaps in the Joint House Committee. I do not know whether this is its responsibility or the responsibility of the Presiding Officers but I think reporters ought to be able to do this.

I have just returned from a Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference in Fiji attended by some 180 members of parliament. There was no restriction placed on any of those members in the plenary or the panel sessions as to the type of clothing those members of parliament had to wear. Very few members of parliament who took part in any of those sessions were strapped up in collar and tie. They were able to do their work in open-necked shirts or their national dress. I think it is much easier to work in such clothing. It is much easier for us as members of parliament to take that responsibility and suffer the consequences. Of course, the members of the Hansard staff are not in a position to get up and speak for themselves. On this occasion, I make that plea on their behalf.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several points raised might usefully be taken up at this point. I first refer Senator McLaren to the matter of Ralkon Agricultural Co. which he did not mention by name.
—I did not mention it by name.

—The honourable senator did not mention the name but it is the Ralkon Agricultural Co. to which he referred. I remind him that the company itself called off the Ombudsman before he brought down his report and that it is quite competent for the company to go back to the Ombudsman. But, by taking away the complaint, it prevented the Ombudsman from putting in a report. If the honourable senator wants a report on the Ralkon situation, I suggest that he goes to the Ralkon people and asks them to reactivate the Ombudsman report. I believe the company may have pulled it off because it may have believed that the report may not have been positive to its case. I do not know that. I suggest that, if in fact it has no worries, it should go back to the Ombudsman and have the report reactivated.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLaren also raised a matter concerning the fact that we have eight Estimates committees. He indicated that he thought this might have been done in some way to make the job of honourable senators more difficult. In fact, it makes the job of Ministers more difficult. This is not something that Ministers wanted to promote. We have six Ministers in the Senate and eight Estimates committees. It has taken a lot of work for Ministers to schedule their own attendance at committees. In fact, it was a response to requests from Government senators who felt that, as the committees were previously constituted, honourable senators had less of a chance to play a part and to make their recommendations.

I will take honourable senators through the departments reviewed by the Estimates committees. Honourable senators will find that the first standing committee listed alphabetically on the Notice Paper is Constitutional and Legal Affairs. They will notice that group A includes the Department of the Attorney-General. The second committee is Education and the Arts and group B includes the Department of Education, the Department of Communications and the Department of Home Affairs. The third standing committee listed alphabetically is Finance and Government Operations. Honourable senators will notice that group C includes the departments of Treasury and Finance and the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

What has been attempted is to bring the Estimates Committees in some logical way into line with the standing committees. In terms of the needs of individual senators, that makes a lot of sense. It makes the job of Ministers more difficult. Certainly it has not been done in any way to try to make the job of honourable senators seeking information more difficult or to make their lives more difficult. I hope that my colleague, Senator Rae, might get up and confirm that that is the case. If honourable senators look at the alphabetical listing of standing committees and the listing of the eight groups of Estimates committees they will find that these follow each other. The honourable senators who make up the standing committees might now be on the relevant Estimates committees if their parties so appoint them. This enables them to look at the same areas. In fact, there might be shared expertise. I think as Senator Rae said earlier by way of interjection honourable senators may wish to follow matters through in a fairly organised fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you get rid of Estimates committees and just have standing committees?
—Senator Georges has just interjected to say that what has been done now may be the preliminary to that second step.
—I will come back and develop that further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the sitting was suspended I was pointing out to Senator McLaren that the fact that there are eight Estimates committees has nothing to do with the convenience of Ministers or a desire to restrict examination of the Estimates. Indeed, if this Committee wished to recommend a return to six committees insteady of eight, I would find that very interesting, but I am not acutally proposing it. I repeat that there are eight Estimates committees in an endeavour to meet the convenience of honourable senators and to try to align those committees with the standing committees.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to respond also to some points that were made about the views of the Executive concerning the Senate and Senate committees. To correct one misconception which I believe Senator McLaren expressed, there is already a House Committee of the Senate, established under Standing Order 35. It just happens that when it sits with the House Committee of the House of Representatives it becomes part of a joint committee. Therefore, it is not necessary to create such a committee; one exists already. I refer the honourable senators to the appropriate Standing Order.

Also, the Government has been moving consistently to try to restrict the size of the bureaucracy and to transfer powers and functions from government to the private sector where that is appropriate. At the same time, the Government has been pleased to see the expansion of the committee system. The power and prestige of the committees have been increasing. Far from trying to restrain that trend, the Government is pleased to see it. Committee reports attract better responses from this Government that they did from previous governments. Responses are now made regularly and, if possible, within six months. I point out that there are many inputs to government decision-making of which committee reports can well be one. It is not always easy to make decisions, not always possible to agree with the views of committees.

I recall, from the time when I was a committee chairman, that sometimes more than the mere addition of staff is required to make committees more effective. I recall at least one examination some time ago that was conducted of the functioning of the committee secretariat. I believe that it pointed up aspects of management which did require improvement. As a chairman I was very keen to see those comments, which related to evidence of slack time and uneven workload. These are matters, in addition to the question of extra staff, that when I was chairman I would have wanted to take on board. I am sure that when honourable senators speak of the need for more staff they do so on the understanding that the more efficient operation of staff must also be considered.

I understand that staff ceilings have been a problem in the public sector. I can understand why honourable senators would want to raise the matter of staff ceilings. The ceilings required for the creation of positions on committees would be a matter that the President would want to take up. I understand that appropriate action to consider such ceilings and the needs of select committees is already under consideration and that the President is aware of the need for people to man the select committees that the Senate has appointed. I understand also that the President is endeavouring to examine the possibility of raising staff ceilings to prevent staffing problems from arising.

Having said all that, I have no reason to disagree with many of the sentiments that have been expressed. I only mention that members of the Executive, most of whom have served on committees, are proud of the committee system and would want to see it prosper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: — I wish to reply to Senator Baume, who endeavoured to castigate me in regard to two matters. In regard to there being eight Estimates committees he endeavoured to castigate or upbraid me by asserting that I had not scrutinised the Notice Paper with sufficient thoroughness. He stated, if I heard him aright, that the eight Estimates committees are practically identical with the eight standing committees. Upon examination, I find that that is not so. He also implied that it was the fault of the Australian Labor Party; that our nominations were not such as to ensure that the people on each of the committees would coincide. That is not the case either. We find that Government members also are to be found on different committees, so again Senator Baume's argument falls to the ground.

SPEECH.PARA: When I referred to the splitting of these committees-probably the Minister did not hear me-my argument was that some members of the Opposition had become so expert at Estimates committee hearings that they were an embarrassment to the Government. I believe that is why the estimates for the Parliament and those for the Department of Administrative Services were assigned to different committees. One could not then pursue concurrently the expenditures in the two departments, which, in many cases, are interwoven.

Also, I was particularly disappointed to hear the Minister mention the name of a company that I was careful not to mention. I remind him that I if I tried to raise it in the Parliament now he would say to me immediately that it was sub judice-before the court. Despite this, as a Minister he chose to try to belittle me and suggest that I had not advised people of the right way to go about things. I will say no more on the matter unless Senator Baume prefers to provoke me at some point before the court hands down its decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to try to assure Senator McLaren that, notwithstanding what might appear to be the situation concerning his point about the development of a degree of expertise, the re-organising of the structure of the Estimates committees and the attempt to parallel them so far as is possible-I emphasise 'so far as is possible'-with the standing committees was at the instigation not of the Executive. It followed a considerable amount of work by a group of honourable senators who were trying to see the Senate's committee system develop further and become more efficient.

SPEECH.PARA: Whatever the honourable senator may think-perhaps it could be the subject of a debate at another and more appropriate time-I assure him that I can affirm that it was not as a result of an Executive plot, that it was not at the instigation of Senator Peter Baume or anyone else in an attempt to try to break up the existing expertise. I like to think that it may prove eventually to have been a step forward, one that will make the system work more efficiently from a staffing point of view in particular and, I hope eventually, from a membership point of view. I hope that a greater and continuing expertise will be developed and available as a result of the combining of staff from the standing committees and the Estimates committees which will make the whole committee system more effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it an all-party group which made the decision?
—I take the matter no further. An all-party group is considering further matters which have been discussed. But this was a suggestion which came from a group of Government senators.
—It was done by the Senate.

—It was eventually done by the Senate. I just want to say that, whatever Senator McLaren may suspect about the matter, the initiative for it did not in any way come from a desire to break up the existing expertise. That is the point I wanted to make by way of explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point I wish to make concerns the comments of the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney. He is not in the chamber at the present time, but I think it ought to be put on the record that the importance of the Committee of the Whole should not be diminished by the fact that Estimates committees have scrutinised the expenditure of the various departments. The Estimates committees were set up to scrutinise the Estimates carefully and to enable honourable senators to come into direct contact with public servants and to ask questions and receive answers directly from them. But in dividing up responsibility for that scrutiny between seven or eight Estimates committees it was never intended that the importance and responsibilities of the Committee of the Whole should be diminished. In fact, it was clearly recognised that honourable senators could not attend the hearings of all Estimates committees, especially as the hearings of at least two such committees are held at the one time.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, I refute what Senator Chaney suggested, or perhaps advised; namely, that we ought to truncate the proceedings of the Committee of the Whole. It is very important that the Committee of the Whole consider the Estimates and that it do so fairly quickly, examining them line by line, until we complete consideration of them. Many questions have been asked. Examination of the Estimates by the Committee of the Whole gives honourable senators who have not had an opportunity to attend certain Estimates committee hearings an opportunity to ask questions and to receive answers. For instance, I was not a member of the Committee in question at any stage but I was interested to hear in the debate this afternoon the proposition which you put, Mr Chairman; namely, that the responsibilities of the Joint House Department should encompass the administration of the Parliamentary Library and the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and that it ought to take upon itself-

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not support that.

—I know that he did not support that proposition but I was very interested to hear his criticism of it. I heard for the first time that it was a possibility. I view such a proposition with horror, especially with regard to Hansard and the Library. But there are other areas of administration which are at present the responsibility of the President and which should remain so. I take it, Mr Chairman, from what you said, that the Senate would resist strongly any attempt to bring those areas under the responsibility of the Joint House Department. I can understand the Joint House Department being responsible for security measures and the attendants but it should not intrude into those areas which have a special significance and a special character. We have here an instance of a situation in which the Committee of the Whole can be made aware of a proposition and honourable senators can enter into debate on it and support or criticise it. I take it that the remarks made by Senator Chaney were his own opinion, based on the fact that he would like to see the program disposed of quickly. He is an ex-Government Whip and, of course, his purpose as Government Whip was to get the legislature to dispose of a program as quickly as possible. However, he should not impose his views arbitrarily upon the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter I raise is the cost of operating the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I do not know whether the earlier reference to this matter was a criticism-perhaps I could be advised on that. I was quite surprised to get the impression that it was being suggested that, because the Senate committees were not receiving sufficient finance to enable them to operate effectively, we should look at another committee to see whether its expenditure could be reduced. The best way to deal with the problem is to look at the fact that the Public Accounts Committee is staffed effectively and it needs the staff which it has. It needs its budget in order to carry out its work effectively. If other Senate committees do not have sufficient funds, we ought to increase the budget for those committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an invidious comparison, isn't it?

—I wish the honourable senator could explain that to me. For only some 18 months I have been a member of the Public Accounts Committee. I have been a member of various other Senate committees as well. The Public Accounts Committee meets regularly twice a week throughout the session and during the recess its workload is tremendous. In fact, the honourable senators who are members of the Committee find it very difficult to cope with the tremendous burden. The Public Accounts Committee is also the Committee which works very closely with the Auditor-General. Its work should not in any way be limited or truncated by budgetary requirements.
—Nor should other committees.

—I agree with that. If that is the proposition, I have no argument with it. But if the proposition is that we should be critical of the budget of the Public Accounts Committee I disagree. We should not be critical of that; we should be critical of the fact that the other committees are not receiving sufficient funds to carry out their work as effectively as the Public Accounts Committee carries out its work. For instance, the Public Accounts Committee is again looking at a reference for which Senator Chaney's Department is still responsible; namely, an overpayment of $40m. The Committee investigated an overpayment of $135m. It is investigating all sorts of shortages revealed by the Auditor-General and any decision which affects the Committee's ability to work should be resisted.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer once again to the financing of the Senate committees. The Senate committees, especially the standing committees and the select committees, perform a very effective function, as honourable senators will know. That is not self-adulation; that is a fact of life. Let us consider the situation of the Senate committee which is now called the Rae Committee. That Committee, over five years carried out an investigation into securities and exchange issues. If the investigation had been conducted by a royal commission it would have cost us $2m or $3m. Honourable senators might recall we had a Senate committee which looked at off-shore petroleum resources. It brought down a report and possibly cost the Senate $30,000 or $40,000, if that. The royal commission which covered almost the same area but which did not canvas the problem as well as the Senate Committee covered it cost the taxpayer $1.5m.

I put it to the Committee and the Parliament as a whole that the work of the Senate committees and the quality of the reports which emerge from them are such that the amount of money spent on them is negligible and should not come into question at all. Rather, we should be looking at funding the committees in such a way that their work is in no way diminished. If it costs $117,000 to fund the Public Accounts Committee, it is reasonable to expect that some of the Senate committees which have important references should be funded equally. Since the funding that the committees need is not taken up by travel expenses or, for that matter, fees for committee members, it follows that extra money would go to staffing the committees. I think it is absolutely necessary that when a Senate committee begins a specific inquiry it should be able to build up its staff by bringing in experts in the area which is being investigated. Otherwise the small amount of money that is spent is wasted. It is far better to spend three or four times the amount of money that is being spent at present and get a good result than it is to save money and get a poor result.

In spite of that, I think the reports that come down from the Senate committees are valuable documents which have a continuing value in the area of research. I am supporting the propositions that are being brought forward to upgrade the support for Senate committees. If some rationalisation between the standing committees and the Estimates committees can be achieved and that leads to extra staffing and facilities, by all means we ought to expedite that. I would have liked to make one or two other criticisms but I think Senator McLaren covered them. It is quite comforting to hear Senator McLaren again. One realises that he has been missing. He is missing at the moment. Sitting here is like having a set of headphones on and the only voice coming through happens to be that of Senator McLaren. Nevertheless, this chamber missed him while he was away and certainly will not miss him if he happens to go away again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it from the fact that no other honourable senator rose to speak that what honourable senators wished to be said in relation to the Parliament has been said. That being so, I pass on to drawing attention to one or two other parts of the report of Estimates Committee A. In relation to the Attorney-General's Department, the Committee expressed its enthusiasm for the fact that the Attorney-General's Department had responded to some suggestions and requests from the Committee in relation to the provision of information and had no further comment to make which it would seek to have the Senate take into account in relation to its consideration of those appropriations.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the Department of Industrial Relations, the Committee in its report referred to the fact that whilst it had previously expressed its concern about the extraordinary accurate estimating and about whether it was not an example of estimating and spending up to the amount of the estimate, we found that an inquiry into the estimating practices and control procedures of the Department and the Industrial Relations Bureau which had been conducted by the Department of Finance had shown that those practices and procedures were satisfactory. The Committee makes no further comment in relation to that.

However, in respect of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs I wish to draw attention to the fact that the Committee found that it was confronted with a one-line appropriation in relation to the National Companies and Securities Commission. This matter arises as a result of the fact that that Commission is established under a ministerial council made up of Ministers of the Commonwealth and each of the States. There was a suggestion that it was not possible to provide to the Senate Estimates Committee and, therefore, to the Senate before it dealt with the appropriations any details at all of how the money sought would be expended. That matter was expressed as being one of some concern if it inevitably arises, as a result of the adoption of the Federal approach of a joint Commonwealth and State commission. If being accountable to everyone means being accountable to no one, that is a matter of some concern which this chamber may wish to take up if it finds that the position is repeated. I have reason to believe that it is not likely to be repeated and, therefore, I do not wish to pursue it in any further detail.

The next matter to which I would like to draw attention is referred to on page 9 of the Committee's report. This matter was raised earlier by Senator McLaren and it has been raised by various honourable senators over the years. This is the problem which I would describe with the words 'program evaluation'. The fact is that in respect of a particular government program there are appropriations which appear in a number of different departments and in a number of different divisions within a department. It is very hard for anybody who is a member of one Estimates committee to be able to find out effectively the total costing of that program and whether the results of the program represent an effective use of the total amount of expenditure.

The suggestion made by Estimates Committee A on the bottom half of page 9 is that it would appear that there is no reason why the explanatory notes should not be added to a little further. I hope that this at least could be pursued without a commitment being given at this stage unless, by some miracle, the advice of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) is such that it enables him to give a commitment. I hope the matter can be explored and that the explanatory notes could provide a cross-reference to other parts of a program so that anyone interested, including the members of the Committee receiving those explanatory notes, would be able to find where other parts of the program were provided for.

I understand that in at least some cases, if not all, the internal working records of the Department, which are prepared at the same time as part of the total explanatory notes, contain that information so that no extra work ought to be necessary in providing the information as part of the explanatory notes. Estimates Committee A commends that thought and seeks a response in due course as to the practicality of that course being followed to enable a more effective program evaluation role to be fulfilled by Estimates committees and by the Senate. On behalf of Estimates Committee A, those are the matters to which I seek to draw attention and which arise out of the Committee's report.

INTERJECT.PARA: Department of Home Affairs and Environment

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the three requests for amendment to the estimates for the Department of Home Affairs and Environment which have been circulated in my name. The purpose of these requests is a simple one. It is to bring a series of separate grants to arts bodies back under the control of the Australia Council, the body set up by the Government to decide on such grants. There is no increase in the Budget outlays; it is just an overdue administrative straightening out. What has happened in recent years has been that various bodies-the Australian Opera, the Australian Ballet, the Elizabethen Theatre Trust Orchestras and Artbank-have managed to bypass the Australia Council and get their funds direct from the Cabinet, despite frequent protests by the Australia Council. It is not difficult to see how this situation has come about. Many politicians and public servants fancy themselves as latter day Medicis. The trouble is that they are usually totally unqualified to make such critical artistic decisions. Besides, as they all eventually realise-some more slowly than others-it is terrible politics. For every friend one makes with a generous arts grant one makes 10 enemies who do not get what they think they should. That is bad politics in anyone's terms.

SPEECH.PARA: It is for this reason, as well as the requirements of efficient arts administration, that we, in common with other countries, have adopted the so-called arm's length system in administering the arts. Under the arm's length system the Government decides the total amount available for the arts, appoints a body of experts to develop policies and decide on the actual distribution of grants between the many competing applicants and to take any resultant criticism. The Australia Council has been set up to perform this role. The Council was restructured last year to reduce its size to 14 members, the majority of whom must be arts practitioners, and to ensure that it had control over the activities and expenditures of the seven specialist boards, whose members are experts in their fields. But there had been a feeling that some of the boards were making idiosyncratic decisions. The new arrangements ensure that the Council is able to impose a coherent policy. So far, so good.

It would seem simple to give the Australia Council whatever funds the Government thinks appropriate and leave the Council to get on with it. Of course, that would not please everyone. No one can possibly do that with arts grants, however lavish the funds. But at least the funds would be distributed by knowledgeable people, in accordance with a coherent policy, and there would be time for those making the decisions to consider the details of the competing demands and the consequences of their decisions and to detect padded budgets and so on. It is routine, of course, but it is time consuming. It must be done if our arts administration is to be efficient and fair. This is the way our system is supposed to work, but it is not the way it actually works. The authority of the Australia Council has been steadily eroded, a situation which is continued in these estimates. I have complained to successive Ministers year after year and have been fobbed off with some story such as: 'It is just a temporary situation; we are sorting it out'. I think that it is time to take a stand.

Turning to individual items in the estimates, the first to be discussed is Art Bank, which is part of Division 330. Art Bank was established two years ago to co-ordinate all Commonwealth art lending activities and to acquire works of art for placement on hire in public places. Art Bank this year gets $425,000. Let us compare this with the Visual Arts Board, one of the seven boards of the Australia Council. One function of this board is also to commission and place works of art in public places as well as to support the acquisition and exhibition of works of art. It, not Cabinet, would surely be the most suitable body to decide how much of the available funds should be allocated to Art Bank. The same argument would apply to the Australian National Gallery, which this year will receive $10m for construction and $15m for administration and acquisition of works of art. I think that the Government, having made the decision to establish a national gallery and a national collection, is correct to fund its setting up directly. But once the gallery is finished and open, its administration costs and its grants for further acquisition should come under the Australia Council, to be considered by experts in balance with the other demands on the available funds for the arts as a whole. But that is a problem for the future. I do not suggest any immediate change to these National Gallery grants.

The votes that I think should be changed, and should be changed at once, are the allocations of $3.337m to the Australian Opera, $1.602m to the Australian Ballet Foundation and $2.740m to the Elizabethan Theatre Trust orchestras. These are part of the Australia Council vote, but they are not under the control of the Australia Council. Cabinet decides how much these organisations get. The Australia Council has control over only its vote for administrative expenses and for an item entitled 'General Support for the Arts'. The trouble is that the Australia Council is assisting at least five other opera companies, at least 14 other dance groups and at least five other orchestras out of the vote under its control. Obviously there should be co-ordination between the grants. Equally obviously, there will not be a sensible result if arbitrary decisions about some of the companies are made by one body and the remainder by another-a sort of artistic competition in pinning the tail on the donkey.

Are the Cabinet decisions arbitrary? How does Cabinet decide the amounts? What Cabinet decided was that the flagships-a deplorable expression, by the way-the Opera, the Ballet and the Trust orchestras should receive the same amount in real terms as last year and the Australia Council should receive the same amount in money terms as last year for everyone else. This is, I suppose, a clear decision, although it is not a very sensible one. I do not suppose it is reasonable to expect the Cabinet, when dealing with an expenditure of $40 billion, to delve very deeply into the expenditure of a few millions or to consider the relative value of alternative uses of these funds. Cabinet just makes a broad brush decision and moves on to the next item, which is, of course, why such decisions should not be made by a busy Cabinet but should be delegated to a less busy expert body.

The trouble is, as I have said, that the Cabinet decision was not very sensible. The maintenance of the non-flagship arts funds at a constant money level does not work out that way, because the administrative costs of the Australia Council have to come out of these funds before they are distributed. These administrative costs have risen by 10 per cent this year. As a consequence, the funds available for distribution to arts bodies and individuals are down sharply, by 2.2 per cent. Of course, a drop of 2.2 per cent in money terms would mean a drop of at least 12 per cent in real terms. As the complaints start to come in to senators, I think they will realise how severe the cuts really are.

What about the 10 per cent increase for the three flagship companies-the amount needed to maintain their grants constant in real terms? At least one of these is very peculiar indeed. The Australia Council recommended that this maintenance of real value should apply to the Australian Opera but that the Australian Ballet should receive no increase in funding on the grounds that as it made a profit of $322,000 last year and has accumulated funds of $2.5m there was no justification for an increase in Government support. Yet the Ballet grant will go up when almost every other grant will go down. I emphasise that my remarks have nothing to do with the present problems of the Ballet, although these have been brewing for a long time. The impotence of the Government is ominous despite the fact that as the paymaster it should be able to impose its will. This emphasises the lack of an independent, informed intermediary which, using the privileges of the piper, could have headed off the problems of the Ballet before they reached the present crisis.

This direct Cabinet involvement is, as I said earlier, terrible politics. The Opera and Ballet are widely, though a little unfairly, regarded as Sydney and Melbourne companies. For the Government to increase their grants and to cut back on everyone else will cause great resentment. It may be the right decision but the question is who should make it. It is clearly in the Government's interests that such decision should be made, and should be known to be made, by an independent professional body. I am suggesting that all these grants should be collapsed into the single vote entitled 'General Support for the Arts' and distributed by the Australia Council at its discretion. In practice, there would not be much alteration for the flagship companies this coming year although some trimming should be possible in the Ballet grant to the benefit of other arts bodies. But major shifts are neither possible nor desirable, for expenditures are necessarily planned a long way in advance and major companies such as the Ballet and the Opera need some confidence that they will have reasonable maintenance of funding. I do not think the Cabinet is likely to be a better basis for this assurance than a professional body such as the Australia Council.

What objections are there to what I propose? I have really heard only two. One is that the Australia Council would not support the flagship companies properly, that it would deliberately underfund them as a means of blackmailing the Government into making more funds available for the arts. I do not know who planted this idea, although I have my suspicions, but it is most insulting to the artistic integrity of the Australia Council. Since the 1980 reorganisation, all major changes in funding have to be made by the Council itself, so no one should fear a board running wild. I am sure that the Council is fully aware of the great national artistic asset represented by the Ballet and the Opera and the importance of funding them adequately. To be sure, the Council would look at their proposals with a more informed and critical eye than is possible for a busy and uninformed Cabinet. After all, that is what the Australia Council is for. But I am sure that the Australia Council would foster these two major world class companies. I cannot for the life of me imagine what the Government is worried about. After all, every member of the Australia Council and every member of every board of the Australian Council was appointed by this Government and the structure of responsibility was substantially modified in accordance with this Government's wishes. Why cannot they be trusted?

The second argument is that it would be somehow unfair not to increase the Australian Ballet's grant from the Government just because it is running at a profit. This reveals a very peculiar approach to the purpose of government support for the arts. I think that companies should certainly be encouraged to build up reserves to, say, 20 per cent of the annual operating costs-to deal with the unpredictabilities of being an arts entrepreneur. That has already been achieved by the Australian Ballet, generously. What has to be considered is the level of government support which is needed by the Australian Ballet and the relative artistic value of alternative uses of these funds. Different art forms have different cost structures and different possibilities of box office takings and commercial sponsorship. In my limited experience as an entrepreneur I have found classical ballet a very marketable product. Some would also say the Australian Ballet's commercial success has come in part from following the dancing equivalent of Nellie Melba's advice-'sing 'em muck'. But there is no doubt that it is also capable of performances which are superb by any standards. Nevertheless, it is clearly absurd for the Cabinet to override the Australia Council's advice that no increase in the Ballet's funding was justified and to award it a 10 per cent increase-that is, an additional $146,000. I cannot imagine what possible source of professional advice led Cabinet to this decision.

I hope my arguments will have persuaded most honourable senators and I hope also they have persuaded the Cabinet. To encourage Cabinet to make a sensible decision, I point out that what it is doing is flatly contradictory to the draft Federal platform of the Liberal Party of Australia. I should like to draw particular attention to this sentence from that platform:
Particular judgments should be made by those having specialist knowledge.

I could not have expressed it better myself. Sensible administration, proper development of the arts and the draft Federal platform of the Liberal Party all point in the same direction-the direction of these requests. I commend them to the Committee.
