SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must make some comments on the appropriations dealt with by Estimates Committee B and in particular I must respond to some of the points raised by Senator Hamer. It is not the intention of the Federal Opposition to support the requests for structural change in the appropriation described by Senator Hamer. This is not to say that we do not agree with many of the criticisms he has just enumerated with regard to the unhappy consequences of the particular form of the appropriation for the performing arts in this year's Budget. However, Senator Hamer's suggestion that all the funding should be brought back into one central fund and that the flagship companies-the Australian Opera, the Australian Ballet and the Elizabethan Theatre Trust orchestras-should compete for funding from the Australia Council in the same way as the other parts of the performing arts, mainly the boards of the Australia Council, is not a proposal we can support at this particular stage, because it does not address the fundamental reasons for the crisis in the performing arts that we have at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: This crisis is a result not fundamentally of the way the appropriation has been organised but of the inadequacy of the appropriation itself and of the inadequacy of the various structures of administration which have been allowed to develop during the six years of Fraser Government administration of the arts. In the view of the Opposition, there is no point at this stage in trying to readjust the method by which the funding is disbursed between the boards of the Australia Council and the national companies if the overall allocation is as woefully inadequate as it is. There is no point at this stage in saying that the Australia Council should resume the very onerous and demanding task of administering the funding of the Australian Opera, the Australian Ballet and the Elizabethan Theatre Trust orchestras when the administration and the administrative structure of the Australia Council itself is a matter of some concern to the Opposition. So, at this stage, sympathetic as we are to many of the criticisms raised by Senator Hamer and sympathetic as we are to the view that there ought not to be special favoured treatment of national companies simply by virtue of their being national companies, we see no practical sense in supporting the requests that he has described.

I make it quite clear that we are very unhappy with the fact that the Cabinet has chosen to give what is perceived as being favoured treatment to the national companies while ensuring through its paltry appropriation to the Australia Council for general support of the arts, that the Australia Council boards have had to engage in a slashing exercise in regard to the assistance it gives to the various companies throughout Australia. In fact, one of the very unhappy consequences of the division between the Cabinet decision for the national companies and the Australia Council decision for everyone else has been the development of a very destructive rivalry between the supporters of the national companies and the supporters of the various other companies throughout Australia. That kind of rivalry and that kind of competition, I suggest, are quite destructive and unhealthy. It has led to what I believe to be unfair attacks on the national companies from those who feel their own companies are being damaged because of the favoured treatment of the national companies and it has led also to an unsympathetic approach to the problems of the smaller companies by people who are supporting the national companies. So it is altogether an unsatisfactory situation. The Federal Opposition sees no advantage in having national companies versus other companies, fighting each other. We want to see a coherent national arts policy adequately funded so as to ensure the maintenance of all artistically viable endeavours in this country, so as to ensure the assistance of innovation, the creation of new companies and the flourishing of new talent but at the same time the maintenance of the highest possible standards in our national companies. Of course, this coherent policy is exactly what is lacking.

Senator Hamer has mentioned that the ability of the Australia Council to make artistic decisions has been drastically reduced by the decision of Cabinet to ignore the advice of the Council. He did not mention one other reduction in the Australia Council's ability to make choices; that is, the Cabinet decision to allocate $500,000 for an Arts Festival to coincide with the Commonwealth Games in Brisbane next year. That may or may not be a useful initiative in the arts, but it is the sort of decision on which, I agree with Senator Hamer, the judgment ought to have been an artistic one or one made by the expertise available within the Australia Council and not made as a grandstanding exercise by Cabinet.

As I said, the real problems facing the performing arts today and causing a crisis in the performing arts today go much deeper than the method of appropriation. We have, as I speak, a crisis in theatre throughout Australia. The news of the Theatre Board's allocations to various theatre companies throughout Australia hit the media today. Those companies were informed of that today and I, and I presume many other senators, have been inundated with complaints about the number of companies which will go under or whose future will be jeopardised because of arbitrary across-the-board cuts which have nothing to do with the artistic viability of the companies and nothing to with the consumer demand for their services or public approval of their services but only to do with the Government's ideological attack on the public sector which says that there must be across-the-board cuts. We have that sort of crisis in the theatre, and I will go into that in some detail. We also have a situation in which the Australian Ballet, for a long time one of the proudest creations of the Australian arts scene, is on strike, and for very good reasons. We have the Australian Opera going into a massive retrenchment of permanent officers which, although it may lead to some sort of improvement in efficiency, is the sort of drastic action which is controversial, which causes people to become embittered and which causes the public confidence in the administration of the Australian Opera to be very badly shaken.

Let us look at what is happening as far as theatre is concerned. The Australian Council as a whole announced in a Press release on 8 October that there would be a shift in the allocation of money within the Council towards activities of initial creativity. That is a shift which in principle the Opposition would endorse but which in practice, because of the paltry sum that the Theatre Board has had to administer, has meant that many companies, including those engaged in initial creativity and innovative activity, have been severely cut. The Theatre Board has had to deal with a 10 per cent reduction in its own Budget. The amount that it has had to distribute has been less in dollar terms than it was last year, despite the fact that last year inflation reached a figure of 10 per cent. In fact, it has had only $5.4m to distribute this year. The Theatre Board had to set priorities and it decided that its priorities would be dance and young people's theatre, priorities which in principle we would endorse but which have led to a series of decisions which have given rise to my claim today that there is a crisis in Australian theatre.

Most major companies will suffer. The area of drama will bear the brunt of the funding reductions. Eight companies face the prospect of the cessation of all funding. They will receive no funds this year from the Theatre Board. Those companies are: The Australian Performing Group; the Brisbane Repertory; the Ensemble Theatre, New South Wales; the Hole in the Wall Theatre, Western Australia; PACT Theatre, New South Wales; the Stage Company, South Australia; the Theatre Works, Victoria; and the Why Not Theatre, Victoria. The funding of most other drama companies will be cut by a minimum of 10 per cent. The Marion Street Theatre and the Q Street Theatre are in that category. La Boite Theatre in Brisbane will lose all funding for its main season while retaining funds only for its youth activities. I would say that the approach to the La Boite Theatre demonstrates how the setting of priorities by the Theatre Board is simply not possible in the current economic climate. La Boite Theatre was engaged, and I am sure that Senator Georges can endorse this, in innovative theatre and would have, one would have thought, fulfilled the new criteria of the Theatre Board in that it was involved in the development of new talent, new ideas in theatre and so on. It was by no means what one could describe as an establishment theate company; yet it has lost all of its funds with the exception of its funds for youth theatre. The funds for the Nimrod Theatre will be reduced by 15 per cent. Other major State companies, including the Sydney Theatre Company and the Melbourne Theatre Company, face 20 per cent reductions in funds, as do most entrepreneurial organisations, including the Canberra Theatre Trust. So it seems that an establishment theatre providing conventional but very acceptable services year in and year out faces cuts and an innovative struggling company attempting to do something new in theatre also faces cuts. The cake is simply not large enough. That is why we are not persuaded that Senator Hamer's suggestions provide any real solution to the crisis.

When we pass to the Australian Ballet we find an appalling situation. The dancers are on strike. They are on strike after years of frustration caused by poor administration and, I suggest, inappropriate appointments to the Board of the Australian Ballet by the Fraser Government. The dancers have had to endure working under substandard conditions. There have been stories in the media about being forced to perform when suffering injuries. But the most obnoxious feature of what has happened in the administration of the Australian Ballet recently is that an arbitration commission award establishing a certain wage level and certain conditions of performance for principal dancers has simply been set aside by the administrator. The administrator's response to the setting of an award by the arbitration commission has been simply to say: 'We will downgrade you so that you are no longer in the category that will attract this award'. Is it any wonder that the dancers finally felt that they had to go on strike to draw attention to their plight? Indeed, nothing else that they did, I think, would have attracted any attention, sympathetic or otherwise, from the Government, which in the case of the Australian Ballet seems to think that as it has, as Senator Hamer has pointed out, given it an increase in its funds, that is the end of the Government's responsibility and it really does not have any other responsibility towards the company. But it does. That is public money. That $2m is public money which is going to a national company provided for the benefit of the Australian public. The series of administrative crises that the Australian Ballet has experienced should have attracted the serious attention of the Government before today. We have seen two very talented administrators resign or forced to resign-Sir Robert Helpmann and Ms Anne Woolliams. Now we have this current crisis and we have silence from the Government.

When it comes to the Australian Opera, 22 permanent jobs have been cut back. Mr Patrick Veitch, the new General Manager-I think he is the eighth in 12 years-revealed that the company's operating deficit this financial year would be in excess of $700,000, which would bring its accumulated deficit to $1.2m. He said that if strong measures had not been taken immediately the company's deficit in 1982 would have been a further $1.2m. So 22 people who have been working for the Australian Opera are to be retrenched. This is a totally unsatisfactory situation. It seems to me that until the Government is prepared in the first instance to provide appropriate funding for the arts and in the second instance to make sure, in the spirit of public accountability, that those funds are being properly administered by competent boards and competent management, these crises will continue, standards will be reduced and the Australian public will suffer. I simply remind honourable senators that the allocations to the arts in the six years of office of the Fraser Government has been seriously reduced. They are now at a level of about 40 per cent lower than they were in the last Whitlam Budget. Arts funding is now down to 0.07 of total government outlays-a pathetic figure, the lowest of all time and, I believe, an absolutely pathetic response to the real need and the real desire on the part of the Australian public to have a thriving indigenous Australian culture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to comment at any length on the final point raised by Senator Ryan in her speech in relation to the industrial situation in the Australian Ballet, except to say that perhaps it points up to some extent the fact that the dancers and the administrator, in all that has led up to the cancelling of the Brisbane season of The Merry Widow with the consequent refunding of all tickets bought, and I understand that all shows were a sellout, have not had to have quite as close a consideration of their financial situation as one might have hoped they could. SPEECH.PARA: I rise to support briefly the points made by Senator Hamer. I shall not reiterate all the arguments because I thought he made them very capably. I suggest to Senator Ryan that perhaps the Opposition in due course might rethink its attitude toward support of the principle that Senator Hamer puts forward; namely, that the appropriations for the Australian Ballet, the Australian Opera, the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust and Art Bank be part of the general funding for the Australia Council. As I understand it, the point that Senator Hamer strove to make, and I thought made very successfully, was that the present appropriation has put the Australia Council into a difficult position in relation to funding of certain artistic exercises. On the other hand, the positions of the four national companies have been guaranteed by the Government in the amounts given in the separate appropriations. There is a clear suggestion that the Australian Ballet may well not have needed as high an appropriation as it received under this separate appropriation. A judgment could have been made that certain other areas of Australia Council concern and other areas of funding could well have done with some additional money in that area.

One of the benefits of what Senator Hamer suggests in relation to the structure of funding for our arts, in my view, is that it would allow greater flexibility. Senator Hamer said very properly that it is very desirable that artistic concerns make a profit. Some concerns are resigned to not making a profit, but ballet is a popular and profitable enterprise. It is not only the Australian Ballet that has that experience. Given that it has been able to run at a profit, we should all be pleased and welcome the fact that that may mean that the Ballet does not need quite the same level of public funding as it may have needed in other years. I do not conclude that that is necessarily so. Possibly the Ballet could put up a case for itself and say that for some reason it ought to be given preferential treatment over all the other areas of artistic concern with which the Australia Council has to concern itself.

I do not think the Opposition can have it both ways in saying that it would not support this at this stage because its main criticism was of the overall level of funding. I suggest that under those circumstances there is all the more strength to the argument that the Australia Council should be making the decisions in the amounts that go to the Ballet, the Opera, the Theatre and to Art Bank. If there is a real concern about the overall level of funding, we should be very anxious to be sure that there is no feather-bedding in any area of artistic funding. We should be very anxious to ensure that those who do have a genuine claim either for extra money or just to maintain their present position can make it under genuine circumstances. I do not criticise the Ballet or the Opera. I can well understand that they would be very happy with their present position, but I agree with Senator Hamer that they should be put into the same category.

I would like briefly to take Senator Ryan to task over her reference to the Commonwealth arts festival which will be held in Brisbane next year to coincide with the Commonwealth Games. In fact this Commonwealth arts festival, which will be a unique artistic exercise in Australia, replaces a Queensland festival called Warana and is being administered by those who would normally administer Warana. It does not come into the same category at all of the other artistic grants. It is a once-off exercise, a unique opportunity and it does not fit into the overall artistic funding. It has a special claim to a special funding because it is a special, once only exercise. It also comes under other special arrangements which have nothing to do with the Australia Council, but have to do with arrangements that are carried on every year under the umbrella of Warana. Warana is forgoing its festival next year because there is a coincidence and an overlap in time and the administrators of that were very happy to take on the administration of the arts festival.

During the recent Warana festival those who have the principal responsibility on a Commonwealth basis for the arts festival next year came to witness the Warana festival and to talk to the administrators to see what sort of expertise they had and what sort of organisational infrastructure was there that would fit with what they aimed to do with this Commonwealth arts festival. It is a different exercise altogether. It is once-off and it does not in any sense fit into this category. I take Senator Ryan to task because her tongue slid over the words 'grandstanding exercise'. In fact it is an enormously exciting artistic exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —That remains to be seen.

—It certainly has the potential for it. There is no reason why it should not be. It is enormously exciting in its potential in that it will make coincidentally available with a great sporting event what we hope will be a great artistic event. It will certainly be unique. It will give the people of Australia the opportunity to witness close up very high quality artistic expressions from a wide range of cultures within the Commonwealth. That may, in itself, be very helpful and instructive in terms of some of the virtues of the Commonwealth. That becomes a social and political, if one likes, but certainly a cultural exercise and one that does not claim to come into the same artistic category as the Australia Council exercise.
—It comes into the same appropriation and it does not address Senator Hamer's point that it should have been an arm's length artistic policy decision.

—Indeed, but it comes into the category of a special grant. The Government has decided, in response to a request, that this Commonwealth exercise will take place at the same time as the Games. It is not an Australia Council decision. It is a Government decision and a request that came from Commonwealth level. So the funding is done in that sense and it is not an exercise that will be repeated.

SPEECH.PARA: As well as the sadness, at least, that a great deal of Brisbane people feel about the cancelling of the Australian Ballet's season of The Merry Widow, there is also a great deal of sadness about the discontinuance of the general grant to Brisbane Repertory Theatre and the potential and very serious consequences for La Boite Theatre, which is well established in the Brisbane artistic community; a very active community. If anything, I think it points up some of the virtues of Senator Hamer's suggestion. The Australia Council has obviously had to face very difficult decisions and this is one of its decisions. It will be a great loss to Brisbane if the activities of the Brisbane Repertory are diminished significantly as a result of this decision. Brisbane people in particular will find it difficult to square that shortfall in funding in that area with the fact that it has been possible to cancel a booked-out ballet season and to embark on an entire refunding of the money paid in advance for those tickets. It just will not sit well in Brisbane and it points up the contrast.

I did not set out to be particularly critical of the Australian Ballet but it has been pointed out that it has very handsome reserves and that it made a very worthy and worthwhile profit last year. It is that inflexibility that Senator Hamer's amendment addressed, in my opinion, and it is that enhanced flexibility for the Australia Council for the future that I would like Senator Ryan and the Opposition to think about a little more in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a couple of remarks about items which have been raised here tonight. I refer to the problems that the Theatre Board and theatre companies around Australia are facing in relation to funding. I take the point that Senator Ryan raised in relation to the overall funding. I think that this problem which is facing the arts in Australia has resulted from a number of concurrences, basically those to do with the dispersal of population and the allocation of funds to other items. It has therefore been extremely difficult for us to establish and develop within Australia a workable network of small theatre companies producing top quality work.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is only in the last 10 to 15 years that we have developed here in Australia a capacity to put together and present plays of social comment in relation to our own culture through professional and high quality small theatre companies. I would like to draw attention to a particular theatre company in my own State-the La Boite Theatre or the Brisbane Repertory Theatre. This is a valuable theatre company in the Queensland scene because it has done an enormously good job in relation to youth theatre. I think it is well known in Brisbane that it has helped to provide Queensland with a basis for its professional companies as a result of the workshops it has conducted involving youth and teenage groups.

A large number of actors and actresses who are currently working in major theatre companies and in film and television in the rest of Australia have come through theatre companies in Queensland. Probably there would be a much larger number per head of population than any other State. I think that the work that has been done by groups such as the repertory in Brisbane has contributed greatly to this. Unfortunately strictures in respect of giving major theatre companies large allocations has left very little room for the Australia Council to move. As a result, the Council almost inevitably has had to contact the various theatre companies not by way of written application but by telephone to tell them that no longer will they have amounts such as the one we are talking about here-that is a mere $20,000.

I think it would be extremely difficult to imagine any other such small amount having such a large adverse effect on a struggling area within our community as does this amount. The particular theatre I am talking about has provided a wide community variation in terms of the types of plays and presentations it puts on. This theatre also engages in certain other types of activities. Notably, from time to time it has given free performances to unemployed people, pensioners and student groups. This theatre has been innovative in this regard. I want to register my disappointment, and I believe that of a large number of electors in Queensland, that such an action has been taken in relation to one of our theatre companies. We hope that consideration will be given to looking at the types of allocations that have been presented to the major companies and to whether it might be possible to rearrange matters in such a way that a mere sum of $20,000 may be able to be provided to keep companies such as this not only in Queensland but also in other States operating and doing the effective community work that they have undertaken to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak on a different topic in group B. On a number of occasions in this place I have mentioned the number of post-graduate awards that have been made available by the Commonwealth Government. In particular, I made some remarks on this matter when the number was decreased by the present Government. I would like to point out this evening that some information that was given to us in Estimates Committee B suggests that the number of post-graduate awards that are being offered by the Government is still insufficient. In fact, the numbers of awards are fewer than they were five or six years ago. The information that was given to us in Estimates Committee B is that for 1981 there are 3,546 applicants for post-graduate awards. This number has been relatively constant over the last three years. In fact, in 1979, 3,725 people applied for post-graduate awards. In 1980 the number was 3,758 and in 1981 it was 3,546. Against these student numbers, which are up in the 3,000 mark-I imagine that almost invariably there would be those with either first class honours degrees or 2A honours-the number of post-graduate awards offered for 1981 and 1982 is 800. This means that fewer than one out of every four of these applicants will be able to receive an award. It is interesting to note that in 1975, the last year of the Labor Government, 900 post-graduate awards were offered by the Government. This number remained the same in the first year of the Fraser Government, but then there was a steady decline. The number declined in the following year to 800 and then declined to 700, remained at 700 for a further two years, increased to 800 and will remain steady at 800 for next year.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall that, when the numbers were reduced to either 800 or 700, I commented on the reduction in this place to the then Minister for Education, Senator Carrick, who said that he realised that more awards should be made available and that when conditions improved more awards would be made available. The number of awards has been increased to 800, compared with the trough we had at 700 awards, but they are still not back to the original 900 as they were in 1975. I believe that at least 900 awards should be made available so that these people who apply for post-graduate awards have a much more reasonable chance. I have been away from the academic field for some time so I am not quite sure what the quality of a student's academic achievement has to be before he or she can obtain an award. It has been suggested to me that a person will not obtain an award for doctoral study unless that person has first class honours. Probably a number of people with good 2A honours would be able to profit from post-graduate awards to obtain a doctoral degree. Certainly not many of them will do so if the number of awards is kept at the present level.

I suggest to the Government that it has a look at the number of applications received for these types of awards and that it looks at the number of awards granted to see whether this can be increased. It will become even more important if legislation goes through this place-I hope it will not-to charge fees for those pursuing post-graduate awards. If we pass that legislation, a great number of students who would normally have gone on and who would not receive an award or scholarship of some kind will not go on and their further education will be lost to the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a few matters which relate to the appropriations for the Department of Communications and which ultimately, I believe, will call for some rationalisation of policy. I begin by referring to the appropriation for multicultural broadcasting, which is of the order of $25m. I draw attention to the size of that appropriation compared with that for the Australian Broadcasting Commission, which is something less than $240m. The Commission is, by common consensus, a fairly run down organisation at this stage of its career. I suppose that it was for that reason that some time ago the Government set up the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission which, according to the appropriations, cost close to $1m, to examine the future of the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that, in looking at that future, the overall level of appropriations for various instrumentalities be taken into account. I believe that it is fair to say that the Special Broadcasting Service is providing a new, innovative and imaginative service in Australian television through Channel 0-28 in the cities of Melbourne and Sydney-a service which arguably is for middle-class, middle-brow Australians rather than for ethnic communities. This is a debate which must be determined in terms of the identity of Channel 0-28 as a television service. At least it is arguable that that is so, and when one is spending $25m on such a service and only $238m on the Australian Broadcasting Commission, which provides a radio and television network, both regional and metropolitan, throughout Australia, there seems to be some discrepancy in the amounts of money that are being spent.

I would have thought that the services provided by Channel 0-28 have brought a new chink of light into Australian television broadcasting, but the Special Broadcasting Service has a quite legitimate complaint about the extent to which those services are available. For example, it is argued on the basis for fairly empirical evidence that it has pretty low ratings. The Special Broadcasting Service would say at least that that followed from the poor reception available of Channel 0-28 programs in the Sydney metropolitan area, which would affect adversely the viewing of the service. The Service would also argue that it should have the facility to provide programs in Canberra and Wollongong. This can be done for a very small amount of money. I hope that the Government will give urgent consideration to providing those services as a matter of priority to those two cities, whose population has a relatively large ethnic component.

Nonetheless, I believe that in the long term governments cannot avoid the overall decision as to whether one is to have a national broadcasting service at a cost of $238m. In the words of the timid Australian Broadcasting Commission-a sort of mouse that roared Commission-that sum represents a cut of 22 per cent in government funding over the last five years. Five years ago the then Chairman of the Commission, Sir Henry Bland, described the funding of the ABC as being cut to the bone. Since then its funding has been cut still further. Nevertheless, we are still spending $238m on the ABC and a disproportionately large amount on multicultural broadcasting, particularly its television aspects.

The ultimate nettle that has to be grasped, and I think that we were fairly close to grasping it when the legislation to establish an independent and multicultural broadcasting service was debated here, is whether those two services can be rationalised in some way to provide the services of Channel 0-28 to a much wider audience through the medium of a new national broadcasting service-a notion which stems from the Dix Committee's recommendations about the future of the current Australian Broadcasting Commission, recommendations which cost us the best part of $1m and concerning which there has been no response from the Government to date. In fact, the entire issue as to what should be done with the ABC as a result of the Dix Committee's report has tended to degenerate into an absurd argument as to whether the ABC should have commercial sponsorship of programs. Very little serious consideration has been given to the wider recommendations. I am most concerned that this Parliament approach the question of the future of multicultural broadcasting in Australia, and the future of the ABC, by looking to the provision of two national channels for television, one of which would embrace the current excellent services provided by the Special Broadcasting Service through the medium of Channel 0-28.

There has been considerable argument about the question of the funding of the ABC. One of the saddest and most permanently unfortunate mistakes made by the last Labor Government-I was here at the time so that, insofar as there is a collective responsibility to be borne, I share it-was to abolish television licence fees in respect of the Australian Broadcasting Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —We lost hundreds of thousands of votes over it.

—Gratitude is not an electoral virtue for those sorts of things. There certainly was not much thanks for that decision by the Government. But one has to look at the question of alternative sources of funding for an organisation such as the Australian Broadcasting Commission or the national broadcasting service, which it is hoped will be set up consequent upon the recommendations made in the report of the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. If we have a national broadcasting service of that kind and are looking for new sources of funding, one of the ways to achieve that might be in having a second channel providing multicultural broadcasting of various kinds and other broadcasting of a more innovative nature than the ABC currently provides.

SPEECH.PARA: Also, in my view, very serious consideration has to be given to giving the Australian broadcasting system the right to operate subscription television in Australia. The reason for that is quite simple: The ABC is the one organisation in Australia which could provide subscription television services in both the cities and the country. Because of its capacity in terms of networking, it would be able to provide a much wider service, a much less segmented service, than could be provided by private entrepreneurs. Of course, the second aspect is that such service would provide revenue for the ABC and would support some of the more innovative programming which one would like to see embraced by the Australian Broadcasting Commission. So I think it is important, in looking at the appropriations for the Deparment of Communications, to look forward a bit and to see how some of those large items might be at least amalgamated in the interests of providing a better service to the community and, perhaps, a less costly service in overall terms by means of a process of rationalisation in the provision of government broadcasting services.

I want to touch on just two other aspects of the appropriations for the Deparment of Communications. The first is the grants which are made under these appropriations in support of public broadcasting. I draw the attention of the Committee to the fact that the appropriation for that purpose in 1980-81 and in 1981-82 are the same, which means a decline in real terms in grants to the public broadcasting system. Admittedly, if one looks at the appropriations for the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs one will find that some money is made available to public broadcasters for the provision of ethnic broadcasting programs on public broadcasting stations. That is to be commended. But the public broadcasting system in Australia is very much in its infancy. It is not in the interests of broadcasting, either commercial or national, and it certainly is not in the interests of listeners for the public broadcasting system to exist on a shoestring budget.

We have ludicrous situations such as the one we had in Melbourne a few months ago with the launching of a public appeal for radio 3RRR. That is a very popular public broadcasting station in Melbourne. The station would not have been able to continue to operate if that public appeal had not been undertaken and had not been successful. The public broadcasting sector should not be left in that situation. I think that governments should be concerned to ensure the independence of the public broadcasting sector and its viability. It should be quite independent of government on a day to day or budgetary basis from year to year. There is not much point in turning an established public broadcasting sector into a sort of broadcasting equivalent to the Victorian railways system right at the start of its career. It is not very good initiative from governments and it is not very imaginative. In a sense, I suppose it is a waste of money because if a service is provided and it is forced to operate on that basis, it is not a good service. It is an unsatisfactory advertisement for the activities of any government in Australia for it to be provided on that basis.

The only other point on which I comment is the appropriation of approximately $3.5m for the regulation of broadcasting and television in Australia. If that sort of money is to be spent on the regulation of broadcasting and television in Australia, it is very desirable that it be spent on the basis that there is an understanding that there is a firm system of regulation, a system of regulation which is not changed by governments at the instigation of private proprietors in the media to suit their own interests. That is what happened in this Parliament in the rush last May or June to pass legislation and to alter the provisions of the Broadcasting and Television Act relating particularly in that case to ownership of the television station Channel 10 in Melbourne.

It is clearly arguable that the legislation which was passed by this Parliament before the numbers changed-that was the purpose of the rush-in essence was retrospective in its effects and it changed the law. Without going into all the refinements-they were very clever refinements-it changed the law retrospectively to help a particular individual or a particular company in relation to the ownership of that television station. I am not as it were bitching, if I might put it in those terms. I hope I am not taken up by the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) for using an unfortunate term. We are discussing Group B of the Estimates, not discrimination in terminology or anything like that. I am not upset about that decision so much as about the absence of principle involved in that decision; namely, that we can have a system of broadcasting regulation and, at the whim of a particular Minister, or a particular Prime Minister in that case, alter that law to suit a particular person. When that is done, government is becoming scandalous and is likely to be regarded with disrepute in the community, and rightly so. So if we are to have a system of regulation and if we are to pay $3.5m for it, the system ought to be an honest one and clear in its terminology and understanding so that people know where they are going.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the Department of Administrative Services, I raise the situation of watchmen and cleaners who are employed by the Commonwealth around Australia whose future has been put in profound jeopardy by the razor gang decision to have these services performed by private contractors. If one adds the cleaners employed by the Commonwealth directly, I believe the figure is closer to something like 600 men. No doubt the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) will enlighten me and enlighten the chamber if these figures are wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: However, what any figures of this kind tend to conceal are the human implications for those people involved, most of whom who are, in this instance, middle-aged or older and will find it enormously difficult to get any job elsewhere if they are thrown out in the cold, as is now proposed by the Government. Those who are permanent employees-they represent only a proportion of the total-will become eligible for some transitional income support under the operations of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and retirement) Act if they cannot be provided with employment elsewhere by the Commonwealth, which seems probable. But that transitional payment under the CE(RR) Act is only for a limited period and it will be sacrificed by these employees completely if they take the other option which may be open to them in some cases of accepting employment if they are offered it by the private contractors in question because if they accept that latter option they will find themselves subject to the sack at a matter of a week or so's notice and, in the process will lose any entitlement to redundancy or severance pay that they might otherwise have accumulated. So a dreadful dilemma in that respect faces the permanent employees.

An even more miserable prospect faces that very large class of watchmen and cleaners who are in fact temporary employees. In many instances they have had that temporary status for many years-10, 15 or even 20 years in some case. The situation of temporary employees, as I understand it, is that, if the Commonwealth cannot or will not provide employment for them elsewhere within the system-and it seems overwhelmingly likely the case that this will be so-their only prospect of solace, not eligible as they are to the benefit of CE(RR) Act redundancy payments, will be if they are taken on the the staffs of the private contractors concerned. Again there is no certainty whatsoever that that will in fact happen.

So the threat posed by the Government decision-it is a decision that has been made; there are no ifs or buts about it-is a very real one and it is important that, if a decision like this, affecting the livelihood of some hundreds of people around Australia, is to be made, it be justified by some overriding public policy concern that least there will be some substantial saving to the taxpayer. However, it is amply clear that the Government has no such rationale for this decision. Here, as elsewhere, it is simply an ideological matter. This problem of the watchmen-cleaners is one that has been taken up by others of my colleagues. It has been taken up by Senator Ryan in the context of the Australian Capital territory employees concerned. It has been taken up by my learned colleague Senator Mulvihill in the context of the watchmen-cleaners employed in the parliamentary offices in Sydney. I understand it has been taken up also by Senator Coates in relation to Tasmanian employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the sending of that letter, a discussion was arranged with the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) on the evening of 15 October in order, it was hoped, to get some answers. Let me simply record that the occasion, which was attended by Senator Missen on behalf of the Liberal Party members in Customs House, by Senator Siddons on behalf of himself and Senator Chipp, and by myself, was not one that it gives me any great pleasure to recall. I think it is perhaps worth putting on record just what the nature of the Minister's reaction was to the various sentiments that we had expressed in a very open and bipartisan, in fact, tripartisan way on behalf of these employees. In the first place Mr Newman acknowledged that no comparative cost analysis had been undertaken of private contractors as compared with public employees. The Minister said that he expected the cost would be less if it went into the private sector, but he did not know whether it would be less. What was unstated but came through perfectly loud and clear was that he did not care whether it was less or not because what was involved here, as elsewhere in the razor gang exercises as we have been told over and over again, was a matter of principle and philosophy and not one that was necessarily going to be resolved in terms of cash benefit to the taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: The second thing that the Minister said was that he acknowledged that private contractors would not be required to take on any of the displaced workers. He said that the successful private contractor or contractors in the different locations would be briefed that they were expected to take on appropriate workers but that they were under no obligation to do so. (Quorum formed). The third matter that the Minister communicated to us was that he had no information readily available as to whether the employees in question, about whom we are making representations-namely, those of the old Customs House in Melbourne-were either permanent or temporary or what ages they were, these, of course, being crucial considerations if one if determining or trying to assess their future employment prospects. The Minister made it clear that this had not been taken into account in any way by the Commonwealth or himself in implementing the razor gang decision. He went on to say that to the extent that elderly or middle-aged watchmen-cleaners would be likely to be replaced by younger men and possibly women employed by the contractor, this would be a good thing because it would improve the security of the building. This is the kind of mentality and attitude with which one is dealing.

The delegation of Senator Missen, Senator Siddons and myself was further told that the Minister would give no guarantee of any kind about the extent to which permanent employees in the category in question would be absorbed elsewhere within the Public Service under the operation of the redeployment provisions of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act. The only thing that he did say in this respect was that he saw it as being unlikely that it would be practicable in all cases for these people to be absorbed elsewhere. He then had no explanation at all for the absence of any promised consultation with the members and senators involved about the new arrangements for access to the building and the securing of it if the present system were changed-an undertaking to have consultations which had been made by the Minister to me and others sometime previously. I acknowledge that when pressed on the matter as far as security and access to the building were concerned he did say that the existing 24 hour service was proposed to be continued under the new arrangements. It will be interesting to see whether that happens.

Finally, when pressed the Minister said that he had consulted with the unions involved by way of writing to the Federal Secretary of the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia, telling him of the new arrangements and including within that correspondence the fact that if certain employees were not continued in employment by the Commonwealth, they would get certain protection under the CE(RR) Act. He did not, however, tell us what the response of the union had been to that particular ex post facto mode of consultation. In fact, I have been led to believe subsequently-although I have not had an opportunity to communicate with the Federal officer of the union-that the Minister has been approached on at least two occasions by union representatives in Canberra on attempted exercises in trying to see him, organised through the honourable member for Canberra, Mrs Kelly, and has on both occasions refused to see the union delegates in question. The Minister has now gone overseas and made it perfectly clear that he is not interested in talking to anybody.

That is the kind of reaction one gets from this Government. I think it is a little case study in itself of the way in which the razor gang is working out in practice. It may be that overall it is the case that the razor gang exercise has been a bit of a damp squib; that it has not carved off the millions of dollars that perhaps we were led to anticipate it would carve off the national Budget when the razor gang cuts were first mooted. Nonetheless, the cuts that have been applied work very savagely in respect of particular individuals and in the case that I am talking about many individuals who have served their nation and, in many instances, us parliamentarians, long and hard and in a very dedicated fashion over a long period. I find it very difficult now to know what more can be done on behalf of these people. Representations are made and arguments are put at the highest level. In making such representations and in putting such arguments one is treated with little short of contempt from the Ministers concerned. It can scarcely be wondered at if, in return, the Minister in question and indeed the Government of which he is a part, is regarded with an appropriate response by those whom he and the Government treats in this way. I think it has been a disgraceful episode and I hope that the Minister will be in a position tonight to tell us that this matter will be the subject of some further reconsideration by the Government, particularly in the event that it should prove to be the case that when the tenders are all in from these various private contractors around the place that the cost savings involved, if any, are not likely to be very substantial. If in fact, there is really no significant saving for the taxpayer involved in these particular changes, which might make them defensible from at least one point of view, I urge that at least by reference if not by the more humane criteria that I have been seeking to articulate, then at least by that colder, harder, commercial criterion the Government will reconsider this decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer briefly to the Australian Electoral Office, a body for which I have a very high regard. During the hearings of the Senate Estimates Committee I asked a series of questions. In one of them I asked for an estimated cost of counting elections right out. In other words, at the moment only in those seats where there is not an absolute majority are preferences actually cast and we can determine what is an accurate preferred vote. My suggestion at the Committee hearing was for the Electoral Office in every seat throughout Australia-the whole 125-actually to distribute preferences until the two remaining candidates are left. The idea of that is that we would get an accurate review Australia-wide of the level of support for the two major parties contesting that election. At the moment all the estimates are based on the Mackerras model of two-party preferred vote and various guesstimates are made for what happened in 1954, what happened in 1961 and 1969 as to which party in fact won. But if the Electoral Office did as is done in South Australia and actually allocated preferences right out, we would have a situation in which we would know Australia-wide what is the total support for the two major parties. I rather naively suggested to Electoral Office officials that in fact it would probably cost $1,200 Australia-wide. However, their reponse was a little more generous than that in terms of cost. I quote the response:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Electoral Office is required in terms of the current legislation to continue the scrutiny of the votes until one candidate has an absolute majority. If that is established on the count of first preference votes or as a result of the distribution of only one excluded candidate's preferences, no distribution or further distribution is prescribed. To proceed further might therefore require an amendment to the law.

However, if distribution of all preferences was to be undertaken in accordance with the steps set out in the Commonwealth Electoral Act, the Australian Electoral Office estimates that this would take approximately 350 man hours per Division. This estimate is based on the re-examination of ballot papers at a rate of 200 per hour plus a time component for the opening of the sealed parcels and individual envelopes which contain the ballot papers for each candidate from each counting centre.
At a salary cost of say $7 per hour, the cost for each Division would be in the order of $2,450.
(Quorum formed). The response continued:
This is only an average because the number of electors voting in each Division varies considerably and the number of candidates varies from Division to Division.

At the October 1980 Federal Election the results in 85 Divisions were determined on the basis of the count of first preference votes. Of the other 40 Divisions, the final result in 39 was obtained only after a full distribution of all preferences and in the remaining Division after a partial distribution. At the estimated average cost of $2,450 per Division the cost of completing preference distributions in the 1980 election would have been in excess of $200,000.

My initial naive estimate of $1,200 skyrocketed to $200,000. In actual fact, I am not particularly happy with the reply from the Electoral Office. It contains many assumptions that anyone who has ever been involved in counting would automatically dismiss. For a start, in any recheck of the votes you do not average 200 votes an hour. I have had occasion to be scrutineering when a certain official did average 200 votes an hour and he was never rehired by the Electoral Office. The best persons to count the votes are bank tellers who like to play poker. Such people are the quickest and the most efficient. I estimate that around 400 to 500 votes an hour is a more realistic estimate. However, my real question related only to the distribution of minor party preferences. So there is no need to recount the major party votes. That is not done at present in seats where preferences are not distributed. I see no reason why it should when we actually distribute preferences of minor parties in those seats where there is an absolute majority. It might be argued that there will be inaccuracies, but those inaccuracies already exist. The votes in those seats where there is an absolute majority on election night are never recounted. If they were inaccurate they will remain inaccurate. I maintain that the distribution of minor party votes is a matter of opening only those envelopes of the minor candidates.

TALK.START.PARA: —About 15 per cent perhaps.

—Probably 15 per cent. I know that Senator Mulvihill has had a lot more experience in scrutineering than I and I will appreciate his comments on this in a moment. But I would imagine that at the most the figure would be 15 per cent per seat. Having watched many of the Federal counts I would estimate that there would be no more than 10 man hours work, and at $7 an hour it would be $70 a division. This would also solve one of the great questions, namely, who in fact did the best Australia-wide, especially in a close count.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter I wish to raise concerns a question that was asked by my colleague Senator McLaren about the comparative costs of deposits. This cost has not been altered since 1965. The Electoral Office undertook to deliver to the Committee what the new costs would be on current prices. I would just like to read very quickly two paragraphs of what was said by the Electoral Office. It said:
In 1965 deposits for House of Representatives candidates were increased from $50 to $100 and Senate candidates from $50 to $200.

The current House of Representatives deposit of $100 represented approximately 176% of average weekly earnings when first introduced in 1965 and now represents approximately 35% of average weekly earnings. The current Senate deposit of $200 represents approximately 352% of average weekly earnings when introduced and now represents approximately 70% of average weekly earnings.

It is quite apparent from those figures that if the level of deposit that was set in 1965 by the Liberal Party was an accurate one, the current level of deposit is absolutely abysmal. This even has an effect on the estimates in as much as at the moment the informal vote in Australian Senate elections is upwards of 11 per cent-in Victoria and New South Wales it is down to about 9 per cent with a range of percentages for the rest of the States.

One of the major costs in any Federal election is in fact the scrutiny of Senate ballot papers. Anyone who has been involved in Federal elections will realise what a long and tedious task that is. The fact that the deposit has remained at its current level has encouraged not only the minority parties-and it is their right to contest elections-but also certain malicious people to encourage other people to nominate for a Senate election in the hope that a higher informal vote will accrue. Figures calculated on a percentage of current average weekly earnings would be something like $800 for the House of Representatives and $1,500 for the Senate. I am not suggesting that we necessarily have to set the figures that high but I should think we should set them at a realistic level based on a percentage of average weekly earnings as was the case in 1965. But the practice has changed since then.

I also indicate that the Electoral Office is operating under what I think is an absolutely outmoded electoral Act, an electoral Act that has not been altered substantially. Attempts were made during 1972 to 1975 to modernise that Act. But because certain features were unacceptable to the then Opposition all of the changes to the legislation were defeated in this place. I understand, and I think we were given some sort of indication, that some committee reports relating to electoral matters were coming. I understand that Halley's comet is also coming. I am wondering which will arrive first-the new electoral Bill or Halley's comet. I suspect it will be the latter. There is need for the Electoral Office to operate under a modern updated electoral Act so that it can run efficiently and its finances can be allocated properly. It is no use having an electoral Act in the 1980s that exists mainly to deal with the problems of the 1930s.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply want to associate you, Mr Chairman, Senator Childs, Representative Les McMahon and Senator Gietzelt with the lucid exposition that was made by Senator Evans about the plight that faces watchmen and cleaning staff at most of the central offices in the various States. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which section/s of the Health Acts prevent uninsured patients in public hospitals from having doctor of choice if those doctors are available and/or have made contractual arrangements with those hospitals.
(2) If there are no legislative prohibitions to uninsured patients receiving treatment from doctors of choice in public hospitals, has the Government laid down any guidelines to prevent this.

(3) If there is no legislative or administrative barrier, what is the basis for the statement by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) on 12 August 1981 that 'people with hospital only insurance do not have a choice of doctor while in hospital'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) There are no provisions in the Health Insurance Act or the National Health Act which preclude any patient, with or without hospital and/or medical insurance, from having doctor of choice in a public hospital. Where a hospital inpatient chooses a private doctor he/she is required by the public hospital (State Government) to meet the charges, on a fee-for-service basis, for the medical services provided and the appropriate level of public hospital accommodation charge. Such medical charges are met through medical insurance or directly out of the patient's own pocket.

Doctors employed by a public hospital, whether on a salaried, sessional or contractual basis, are allocated by the hospital to patients choosing to be treated by hospital doctors. Where a patient exercising the right to doctor of choice chooses a hospital doctor who has a right of private practice, charges on a fee-for-service basis are raised by or on account of that doctor. Hospital doctors without right of private practice are allocated by the hospital.

(3) Senator Peter Baume's statement was made in the context of the new health insurance arrangements which commenced on 1 September 1981. Senator Peter Baume was pointing out that hospital only insurance does not provide coverage for the medical charges associated with making a choice of doctor. These must either be covered by medical insurance or out of the patient's own pocket. Senator Peter Baume's statement was aimed at bringing attention to misunderstandings which might arise in the minds of some Australians that they might be able to take hospital insurance only and also choose their doctor to treat them in hospital without having to meet the fee-for-service medical charges involved in one way or another.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Telecom Australia planning to reduce its manpower requirement by 2000 over the next year.
(2) It is a fact that Telecom will engage no artisan apprentices at all during the current financial year.
(3) Are these reductions designed to further weaken Telecom so that it can be dismembered without public outcry.
(4) If that is not the reason, why has the Government decided to further aggravate the level of unemployment by reducing job opportunities in Telecom so drastically.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telecom Australia was advised in May 1981 that the June 1982 manpower level had been fixed at 2000 below the number expected to be employed at June 1981. The 1981-82 Manpower Plan approved by the Commission has been designed to implement this decision.

(2) During 1981-82 trainee intakes will be for courses which are specifically related to telecommunications. Telecom will be increasing trainee intakes from 1600 in 1980-81 to a planned level of 1726 during the current financial year. Of this intake, 414 will be apprentice technicians (telecommunications) and a further 201 will be technicians (telecommunications)-in-training-a bridging course to allow assistant technicians to obtain trade qualifications and advancement to technician positions.

(3) and (4) The Commission is obliged by its charter to make its telecommunications services available throughout Australia for all people who reasonably require those services, and in performing its functions to have regard to the need to operate is services as efficiently and economically as possible.

The activities of the Australian Telecommunications Commission are currently the subject of a major review. The terms of reference and the names of the members of the Committee of Inquiry were announced on 23 September 1981. This inquiry will examine and report on:

(a) the extent to which the private sector could be more widely involved in the provision of existing or proposed telecommunications services in Australia either alone, in competition with or in conjunction with the Australian Telecommunications Commission;
(b) what consequential changes may be necessary in the statutory functions, duties, financial objectives and monopoly provisions of the Commission; and
(c) the effectiveness of the Commission's operational policies and organisational arrangements.
The Committee of Inquiry is expected to report within twelve months.
The strength of Telecom is not determined by the number of its employees. Any suggestion as to its dismemberment arises from the words of the honourable senator not the intention of the Government.
The staff requirements of Telecom relate to its capacity to meet its statutory responsibilities not to the general level of employment in the community.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications the following question, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Telecom planning to let a contract for the supply and maintenance of computers for its telephone directory assistance services.
(2) Will these computers have access to unlisted as well as listed telephone numbers.
(3) What supervision is planned of the company which supplies the computer, especially if the company is to carry out all maintenance of the equipment instead of Telecom employees.
(4) Will this supervision prevent misuse by the company of information stored in the computer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, a contract for a computerised directory assistance system has been let.
(2) Yes, the system will contain unlisted numbers, but access to this information will be restricted to key Telecom management staff.

(3) and (4) The installation and maintenance of the system will be under Telecom control and Telecom is confident that these supervisory safeguards and other security measures built into the system will effectively prevent unauthorised access being gained to unlisted number information by either the contractor's or Telecom's staff.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are negotiations currently taking place between the Australian Agricultural Council and the Queensland Government concerning the declaration of a destocked zone north of a parallel to be agreed upon about half-way up Cape York, for the declared purpose of eradicating infestations of screw worm.
(2) Are there proposals for this zone to specifically include the Torres Strait Island.

(3) Would the result be that those Torres Strait Islanders who have not yet joined the major exodus to the mainland would be denied the right to raise livestock for food in the event that agreement is reached and becomes law.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Senior officers of Commonwealth and Queensland Government Departments responsible for animal health are conducting a field study of an area just south of the Jardine River to determine if a buffer zone free of livestock and feral animals can be established. The aim is to reduce the possibility of any southward spread of screw worm fly should it ever enter the Cape York Peninsula.
Negotiations between Australian Agricultural Council members on the proposal will hinge on the report of the task force carrying out the feasibility study.
(2) No; the Torres Strait Islands are not included in any area under consideration for a buffer zone.
(3) No; Torres Strait Islanders would not be denied the right to raise livestock.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 September 1981 (Hansard, page 494) Senator Watson asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs in the Senate, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In view of the large increase in bankruptcy will the Minister give consideration to placing a time limit in which creditors must lodge notification of proof of debt. Further, is the Minister aware that at present there is no time limit and all too frequently creditors lodge proof of debt after the Receiver in Bankruptcy has notified in the Press his intention to declare a dividend? Would not the Minister acknowledge that considerable time would be saved in the office of the Receiver in Bankruptcy and that creditors would be paid more expeditiously if a time limit of say six months were required in which creditors would have to lodge their claim.
The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The honourable senator has raised issues that will be considered in the context of the further review of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 that was referred to by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs in a media release 81/65 dated 16 July 1981.
The Department of Business and Consumer Affairs is now doing further preliminary work on this matter and comments from interested persons would be welcomed.
Among the specific questions that the Department is considering are the following:
(a) If a time limit were to be imposed, what would the most appropriate period be?
(b) If a time limit were to be imposed, what protection, if any, would be necessary for creditors who:
(i) were not aware of the bankruptcy?
(ii) were not known to the trustee administering the estate? or
(iii) had some other reason for being unable to comply with the time limitation?

(c) Whether a more effective solution to possible delays in administration in each Official Receiver's office would be to adopt the recommendation of the Joint Management Review that where a dividend is not likely to be paid in a particular estate, the trustee of that estate should inform the creditors that:
(i) a dividend is unlikely to be paid;
(ii) they should keep all relevant material to support a proof of debt;
(iii) but they should not lodge such a proof until they are requested to do so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Defence Integrated Secure Communications Network Project

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 September 1981 (Hansard, page 851) Senator Watson asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice, the following question:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Minister comment on whether the development work needed for the Defence Integrated Secure Communications Network system could have been undertaken here in Australia?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The development work associated with the provision of the Defence Integrated Secure Communications Network (DISCON) system involves the design of specific application hardware and software and the integration of computer controller switching, communications security, terminal, network control and management information systems.

On the basis of the previous tenders it is considered unlikely that all of the DISCON development work could reasonably have been carried out in Australia. However, the project will require the transfer of considerable knowledge of advanced digital communications technology to Australia. This transfer will result in the establishment of a higher level of local capability for any further development or future expansion of secure communications systems.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Labelling of Alcoholic Content of Drinks

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 September 1981 (Hansard, page 980) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question, without notice, concerning inclusion of the alcoholic content of drinks on container labels.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The National Health and Medical Research Council at its Ninetieth Session in October 1980 adopted amendments to its standards for beer, cider and perry, wine, and spirits and liqueurs to require a declaration of the percentage by volume of alcohol on the labels of all alcoholic beverages. It recommended that the amendments be adopted by the States and Territories and I am informed that several States are in the process of adopting them into their food legislation.
